L0: Submodule Introduction

Bookmark

Submodule Introduction

The next submodule contains information about two important concepts in the solution development. They are architectural patterns and styles. After completing the following lessons, you will be able to describe the meaning of these terms and to differentiate them, as well as to apply the key principles of architectural styles in the real projects. You will get acquainted with pros and cons of the most common patterns and will figure out how to determine which one is the most suitable for a particular case. Also, this submodule provides description of zero-downtime deployment practices.

Click on the video to watch the Submodule Introduction, or click here to download a text script to find out what you will learn.

The Estimated Time to Pass the Submodule

20 hours

for the theoretical part and quizzes

5 hours

for the practical task

What You Will Learn in This Submodule

Click on the flip cards to learn more about the lessons in this submodule.

L1: Common Principles

Definitions of architectural style and architectural pattern and their scopes. What are architecture design principles and their impact?

L2: Architectural Style: Monolith, Layered, Microservices

Overview of monolith, layered and microservices architectural styles, description of their key principles, main building blocks, pros and cons.

L3: Architectural Style: Event-Driven

Overview of the event-driven architectural style, its principles, its main building blocks, pros and cons.

L4: Architectural Style: Actor Based and Module Based

Overview of actor based and module based architectural styles, their key principles, frameworks, building blocks and applicable languages.

L5: Architectural Style: REST

Overview of this style and its main principles and constraints. Notion of HATEOAS as a REST constraint.

L6: Architectural Patterns: Performance and Scalability

CQRS, Event sourcing and Sharding patterns, motivation for their use and their main principles.

L7: Architectural Patterns: Integration Patterns

Overview of File transfer, Shared database, Remote procedure invocation and Messaging patterns, motivation for their use.

L8: Architectural Patterns: Fault Tolerance Patterns

Overview of Redundancy, Voting, Heartbeat, Leaky bucket counter and Isolation patterns.

L9: Architectural Patterns: Security Patterns

Overview of Federated identity, Gatekeeper, Valet key patterns. Their main principles.

L10: Release Patterns

Green-blue and Canary deployments patterns, motivation of their usage and main characteristics.

Ready to get started? Click on the "NEXT" button.

L1: Common Principles

Bookmark

Lesson Introduction

In this lesson, you will start to master the basics of architectural styles and patterns. First, you will learn the definition of these terms and figure out the key differences between the two concepts. Then you will move to more complicated topics, such as architectural design principles and methods of coupling. Also, the following lesson provides information on cohesion in computer programming.

Architectural Styles and Patterns: Definitions

Despite the name similarity, styles and patterns in software architecture aim to resolve completely different tasks. First, let&rsquo;s clarify what an architectural style is and how this concept is related to architectural patterns.

Click on the flip cards to learn more about the difference between architectural styles and patterns.

Architectural Styles

Architectural styles tell you, in broad strokes, how to organize your code. It&rsquo;s the highest level of granularity. It specifies layers, high-level modules of the application, and how those modules and layers interact with each other as well as the relations between them (e.g., Layered, Client-Server, Monolithic, etc.).

Architectural Patterns

A pattern is a recurring solution to a recurring problem. In the case of architectural patterns, they solve the architectural style problems (e.g., Three-tier, Microkernel, Model-View-Controller, Model-View-ViewModel, etc.).

There is no single definition and clear separation between styles and patterns. As usual, it all depends on the usage context. But there is another point of view on architectural styles and patterns, which allows them to be defined from a different perspective. Below you will find information from another angle.

Click on the tabs to learn more.

An architectural style can be defined as a specialization of element and relation types together with a set of constraints on how they can be used.

An architectural pattern expresses a fundamental structural organization schema for software systems, provides a set of predefined subsystems, specifies their responsibilities, and includes rules for organizing the relationships between them.

Architectural Design Principles: SRP

A software architect&rsquo;s goal is to minimize the complexity by separating the design into different areas of concern. There are the five principles to follow when designing a solution: Single Responsibility Principle or Bounded context; Principle of Least Knowledge, Coupling, Cohesion, Stateful/Stateless. Let&rsquo;s take a closer look and pay attention to each of them, starting with the Single Responsibility Principle.

Click on the video to learn more about the Single Responsibility Principle. Alternatively, you may click&nbsp;here to download a text script to find out what you will learn.

Refer to the&nbsp;EngX360 Clean Design Submoduleto learn more about the Single Responsibility Principle.

Principle of Least Knowledge

The Principle of Least Knowledge (also known as the Law of Demeter) states that any component or object should not have knowledge about the internal details of other components. This approach avoids interdependency and helps maintainability. Suppose one component knows the other component and program&rsquo;s internals by assuming some of its typical implementations. After some time, the other component gets a makeover and changes the internal implementation. Now the assumptions considered by the other component fail, and so the other component will also fail.

It would be best if you always stuck to the public interfaces and did not work on other system components&rsquo; internal knowledge.

Loading&hellip;

Coupling

Coupling is a measure of how strongly one software unit depends on the other software units. A software unit may be of any granularity: methods in a class, classes, subsystems, packages, modules, services, systems, etc. A class with high (or strong) coupling relies on many other classes.

Swipe to see examples of strong and loose coupling.

Now that you have familiarized yourself with the central concept of coupling, let&rsquo;s have a detailed look at several examples that can demonstrate how the interrelation between classes affects the type of coupling.

Click on the hot spots to view examples.

A weaker coupling is present if the classes communicate via a global data structure. The direct dependencies between the classes are released and outsourced to the global data structure. Despite this, the coupling is still very strong: all changes that affect the global data also affect all classes that work with the data.

The classes can mutually access each other&rsquo;s (private) data. This is a very strong form of coupling since you can no longer change one of the classes without considering the other.

If the classes only communicate via method parameters, the coupling is considerably lower: the methods involved contain only essential data. Changes to this data coupling only cause local changes to the relevant methods of the classes involved.

No coupling: a system of connected objects that communicate via messages.

Cohesion

In computer programming, cohesion refers to the degree to which the elements inside a module belong together. Cohesion measures the strength of the relationship between pieces of functionality within a given module. For example, in highly cohesive systems, functionality is strongly related. Cohesion is an ordinal type of measurement and is usually described as &ldquo;high cohesion&rdquo; or &ldquo;low cohesion.&rdquo;

Click on the dots to learn more about high and low cohesion.

High Cohesion

High cohesion means all elements within a component are directed towards performing a single task. It is associated with several desirable software traits, including robustness, reliability, reusability, and understandability.

Low Cohesion

Low cohesion is associated with undesirable traits such as difficulties in maintaining, testing, reusing, or even
understanding.

Cohesion is often contrasted with coupling. High cohesion often correlates with loose coupling and vice versa.

Loading drag and drop problem.

Stateful vs. Stateless

There are two polar types of design principles related to building services called Stateful and Stateless. In computer software, a state is the condition or quality of an entity at an instant in time. Let&rsquo;s view their key advantages and disadvantages.

Click on the dropdowns to explore more.

Stateful service relies on the moments in time and changes the output given the determined inputs and state. In a stateful web service, the response formed from a simple GET request is entirely dependent on the state registered by the server. Without the knowledge of that state, the request cannot be appropriately returned. Stateful service requires a state shared through several requests.

Advantages. Less data to transfer since the state is maintained on the server and you don&rsquo;t need to resend this data every time.

Disadvantages. Synchronization of concurrent requests&mdash;state maintenance and synchronization bring additional complexity, which can also impact performance.

Stateless type is the polar opposite of stateful: any given response from the server is independent of any state. Every request contains all information to be processed.

Advantages. Higher performance&mdash;the server doesn&rsquo;t spend any effort on state and synchronization management.

Disadvantages. More data to transfer to process a request&mdash;you don&rsquo;t keep the object&rsquo;s intermediate state on the server, so all information must always be passed from client to server and back.

Separation of concerns

Each component in the system should be assigned a specific responsibility. Features should not overlap one another, and the users should have a clear understanding of the steps he needs to take to get to a particular feature. It avoids the interdependency of system components and makes the system easy to maintain.

Lesson Summary

In this lesson, you got acquainted with the architectural styles and patterns definitions from different perspectives and learned five main architectural design principles to follow while designing a solution. Additionally, you viewed other principles that should be considered by a solution architect. This knowledge is critical, as all of these principles aim to help overcome countless obstacles when designing software and working with a project team.

L2: Architectural Style. Monolith, Layered, Microservices

Bookmark

Lesson Introduction

The next lesson is focused on the monolith, layered, and microservices architectural styles. You will look through the general overview of each of them as well as learn their advantages and weaknesses. After completing this lesson, you will be able to determine the most suitable style for a certain task and to migrate from one to another in case of necessity.

Definition

A software system is called "monolithic" if it has a monolithic architecture, in which functionally distinguishable aspects (for example, data input and output, data processing, error handling, and the user interface) are not architecturally separate components but are all interwoven.&nbsp;

The term "monolith" is increasingly being used as a generic insult in the same way that "legacy" is!&nbsp;R.&nbsp;Annet (2014)

Viewtypes

A monolith can be considered an architectural style or a software development pattern (or anti-pattern if you view it negatively). Styles and patterns usually fit into different Viewtypes and some basic viewtypes which will be discussed are Module, Allocation and Runtime. A monolith could refer to any of these basic viewtypes.

Click on the hot spots to see the description of the viewtypes.

Module. If you have a module monolith then all of the code for a system is in a single codebase that is compiled together and produces a single artifact.

Runtime. A runtime monolith will have a single application or process performing the work for the system (although the system may have multiple, external dependencies). Many systems have traditionally been written like this (especially line-of-business systems such as Payroll, Accounts Payable, CMS etc).

For an allocation monolith, all of the code is shipped/deployed at the same time. In other words once the compiled code is 'ready for release' then a single version is shipped to all nodes.

If you want to know more please follow the link.

Pros and Cons

Despite the fact that microservice is the latest trend nowadays, the monolithic architecture still has a number of advantages, which might be very useful and helpful while designing a modern solution. Let's take a closer look at the pros and cons of this style.

Click on the dots to learn more.

PROS

  • Traditional approach, easy to implement (develop, deploy)
  • Easy to understand from the architectural point of view
  • Good for scalability in terms of handling additional load from users, adding new application servers

CONS

  • Large artifacts
  • Deployment of the entire application
  • Large and complex codebase
  • Bad for scalability in terms of data volume

Layered Architecture

Layered architecture is the simplest and quite commonly used style in software development. The cost of its implementation is relatively low compare to other patterns. This method is meant to be self-independent; some of the layers are interconnected but do not depend on each other.

Click on the tabs to learn more about layered architecture.

Components within the layered architectural style are organized into horizontal layers, each layer performing a specific role within the application (e.g., presentation logic or business logic, etc.). One of the powerful features of the layered architectural style is the separation of concerns among components/layers.

  1. It can be logical and physical.
  2. Each layer is on top of another layer.
  3. There are well-defined interfaces between layers.
  4. It reduces complexity, improves modularity, reusability, maintainability.
  5. It can affect performance due to communication through all layers.
  6. There are different criteria for layering: most notably abstraction.

The structure of the system is organized into a set of layers. In this strictly layered structure, a layer can only use the services of the layer immediately below it. Many variations of this pattern, lessening the structural restriction, occur in practice.

Normally, requests always go from up to down. A lower layer should never perform a request to the upper layers.

The Open/Closed principle allows skipping some layers intentionally. A similar concept described by the Software Engineering Institute (SEI) is called layer bridging.

Please follow the&nbsp;link to get additional information about Layered Architecture.

Microservices: Definition

The microservice is a software development technique, which is a version of the service-oriented architectural style. Despite there is no unified definition for microservices, they can be described as self-contained pieces of business functionality with clear interfaces. It is common for this type of architecture to be adopted for cloud-native applications and serverless computing. It structures the application as a collection of loosely coupled services.

The smaller services, the smaller responsibilities, and the less coupling, the more infrastructure mess, which leads to more complicated deployment topology/management and support.

Follow the&nbsp;link to have a more detailed look at microservices.&nbsp;

Loading&hellip;

Microservices: Core Attributes and Challenges

Now, when you familiarized yourself with Microservices definition, let's move to their main attributes&nbsp;and pay attention to some challenges you may face while dealing with this architectural style.

Click on the flip cards to explore the core attributes and challenges of the microservices style.

Core Attributes

  • Lightweight SOA
  • Small (easy to understand, quick to deploy)
  • Loose coupling, high cohesion
  • Independent (easier to deploy new versions of services frequently)
  • Faults isolation
  • Accessed using REST; event-driven asynchronous updates

Challenges

    • N monolithic apps, N M services
    • How to partition the system into microservices
    • API Gateway, service registry, load balancer, fault tolerance/monitoring, configuration/properties management

Microservices: Characteristics

Let's move to Microservices characteristics. There is a list of characteristics, and it is expected the microservice architectures have a maximum number from this list. Unfortunately, it doesn't always happen. The main characteristics related to microservices are presented below.

Scroll to overview the details.

Componentization via Services

Component-based architecture&mdash;components are good because of low coupling, independent deployment, and scalability.

Organized Around Business Capabilities

A monolith is split into microservices according to the business "functions", not according to organizational structure.

Products Not Projects

Software is treated not as a job to do, but as a product to be developed over its lifetime. This emphasizes business value for users.

Smart Endpoints and Dumb Pipes

Simple communication with no logic (complex routing, transformation, e.g., ESB) plus smart service that contains logic inside.

Decentralized Governance

In microservices, you might take advantage of different tools and approaches to better suit a task. Responsibility is distributed as well, and this impacts quality.

Decentralized Data Management

Instead of an organizational structure and vendor-licensing driven approach of storing data, microservices use separate databases for each service.

Infrastructure Automation

Extensive use of automated-infrastructure platforms (for example, Amazon Web Services) for both deployment and operations.

Design for Failure

A special attention is paid to designing software which is tolerant to failures as much
as possible.

Evolutionary Design

Making changes and evolving a system processes are promoted, since you can touch a component with no impact on other components.

Microservices: Technology-Agnostic Architecture

The diagram below represents the structure of microservices architectural style, which might consist of different components apart from the microservices themselves. Let's examine the diagram, the layers it consists of, and discover how it works. The following diagram depicts a reference architecture for the microservices architectural style.

Click on the hot spots to learn the details.

Consumer Layer. The consumer layer shows different clients of the product represented by different platforms.

Delivery layer. The delivery layer balances requests, catches static web content, and addresses requests to the right application.

Aggregation layer. The aggregation layer includes the server-side UI application, different sets of APIs for specific clients, which aggregate business services.

Services layer. The services layer contains gateway and discovery services, business services, system services.

Infrastructure layer. The infrastructure layer provides virtual infrastructure for the platform.

API gateway. API gateway and service discovery internal components which provide routing, discovery, balancing and security for the service layer.

Platform services. Platform services provide support for security and microservices management.

Business microservices. Business microservices implement business logic and processes.

Now, when you became familiar with the components of microservices architectural style, let&rsquo;s overview the common flow of request and consider an implementation example.

Watch the video to explore microservices architecture and see step-by-step example of implementation. Alternatively, you may click here to download a text script to find out what you will learn.

Microservice Anatomy

There is a common flow of requests, which is applicable to a majority of types of microservice architecture. Its main stages and components are represented by the diagram below.

API Layer describes a protocol and a contract of interaction. Business Processes and Logic contain main business logic for that particular service. Domain Layer contains domain business objects and repositories for data access. Gateways and HTTP Client allow for redirecting calls to other services. Platform services integration enables you to have service discovery, health monitoring, self-check, etc. And the data access layer contains mappings and drivers for DB communication.

Move the pieces of the image below in order to rebuild the scheme. Click on the piece you want to move, and then on the piece you want to be replaced with the first one.

Lesson Summary

In this lesson, you have learned the definitions and specifics of three main architectural styles: monolithic, layered, and microservices. You've also become aware of the key advantages and weaknesses of each style and figured out the types of applications and solutions they are supposed to be adopted for. Furthermore, you have looked through some principles to be taken into account while working on the solution.

L3: Architectural Style. Event-Driven

Bookmark

Lesson Introduction

In this lesson, you will get acquainted with the event-driven architectural style commonly used in modern microservice-based applications. Within this approach, events are used to trigger and communicate between decoupled services. You will learn the key characteristics of this style, its two main topologies, and their implementation. In addition, the lesson contains a quiz for self-testing.

Event-Driven Architectural Pattern

The event-driven architectural pattern is a common asynchronous architectural pattern used to produce highly scalable applications. It is also highly adaptable and can be used for small applications as well as large, complex ones. Event-driven architecture comprises highly decoupled, single-purpose event processing components that asynchronously receive and process events.

What Is an Event?

An event is defined as a change of a system&rsquo;s state. With event-driven architecture, when an event notification is sent, the system captures this change and waits to send the reply to whoever requests it whenever they request it. The application that received that message can either respond or wait to respond until the awaited change in state has occurred.

In event-driven architecture, an event will likely trigger one or more actions or processes in response to its occurrence. Let&rsquo;s overview the examples of events and the corresponding responses.

Swipe the illustration to the left to see events examples and to the right to see corresponding responses.

Main Topologies

The main goal of applying the event-driven architectural style is to improve scalability and/or performance. There are two main topologies in event-driven architecture. Because the architecture characteristics and implementation strategies differ between these two topologies, it is crucial to understand each one to know which is best suited for your particular situation.

Click on the video to learn more about two types of topologies. Alternatively, you may click here to download a text script to find out what you will learn.

Please follow the&nbsp;link to learn more about the main topologies.

Mediator Topology

The mediator topology is applied for events that consist of multiple steps with some level of orchestration that should be used to process the event. For example, a single event to place a stock trade might require you to first validate the trade, then check the trade compliance against various rules, assign the trade to a broker, calculate the commission, and finally place the trade with that broker. All of these steps would require some level of orchestration to determine the order of steps and which can be done serially or in parallel.

The mediator topology consists of four main types of architecture: event queues, an event mediator, event channels, and event processors. Now, let&rsquo;s take a closer look at these components as well as the main events within this pattern.

Scroll to learn more about mediator topology components.

Events

There are two types of events within this pattern: an initial event and a processing event. The initial event is the original event received by the mediator, whereas the processing events are generated by the mediator and received by the event-processing components.

Event Mediator

The event mediator component is responsible for orchestrating the steps contained within the initial event. For each step in the initial event, the event mediator sends out a specific processing event to an event channel, which is then received and processed by the event processor.

Event Channels

They are used by the event mediator to asynchronously pass processing events related to each step in the initial event to the event processors. The event channels can be either message queues or message topics, although message topics are most widely used with the mediator topology.

Event Queues

It is common to have anywhere from a dozen to several hundred event queues in an event-driven architecture. The pattern does not specify the implementation of the event queue component. It can be a message queue, a web service endpoint, or any combination thereof.

Event Processors

They contain the application business logic necessary to process the processing event. Event processors are self-contained, independent, highly decoupled. Each event processor should perform a single business task and not rely on other event processors to complete its specific task.

Now, when you became familiar with the main concept, let&rsquo;s pay attention to the general mediator topology of the event-driven architecture pattern. For this aim, pay attention to the scheme below.

Click on the hot spots to figure out how the above mentioned components are involved in the mediator topology flow.

Event. To start the event flow, an event is sent to an event queue by a client. It is used to transmit an event to the event mediator.

Mediator. The event mediator gets the initial event. After receiving, it is orchestrated by transmitting additional asynchronous events to event channels in order to perform all steps of the process.

Event Channel. The event mediator uses event channels to pass asynchronously specific processing events associated with each step of the initial event to the event processors.

Event Processor. Listening to event channels, event processors obtain the event from the event mediator and perform specific business logic to process the event.

Mediator Topology Implementation

There are different ways that allow to implement the event mediator. A solution architect should be aware of all these implementation options to ensure that the solution chosen for the event mediator meets your needs and requirements.

Click on the tabs to overview these ways.

The simplest and most common implementation of the event mediator is through open source integration hubs such as Spring Integration, Apache Camel, or Mule ESB. Event flows in these hubs are typically implemented through Java code or a DSL (domain-specific language).

For more sophisticated mediation and orchestration, you can use BPEL (business process execution language) coupled with a BPEL engine like the open-source Apache ODE. BPEL is a standard XML-like language that describes the data and steps required to process an initial event.

One more way which can be used is the case of extensive applications requiring much more sophisticated orchestration (including steps involving human interactions) refers to mediator implementation using a business process manager (BPM) such as jBPM.

Mediator Topology Example

This section is aimed to illustrate how the mediator topology works. Imagine that you are insured through an insurance company, and you decide to move. In this case, the initial event might be called something like relocation event. The steps involved in processing a relocation event are contained within the event mediator. For each initial event step, the event mediator creates a processing event (e.g., change address, recalc quote, etc.), sends that processing event to the event channel, and waits for the processing event to be processed by the corresponding event processor (e.g., customer process, quote process, etc.). This process continues until all of the steps in the initial event have been processed. The single bar over the recalc quote and update claims steps in the event mediator indicate that these steps can be run simultaneously.

Move the pieces of the image below in order to rebuild the scheme. Click on the piece you want to move, and then on the piece you want to be replaced with the first one.

Broker Topology

In contrast with the mediator topology, the broker topology has no central event mediator. At the same time, the message flow is distributed between event processor components in a chain manner through a lightweight message broker (e.g., ActiveMQ, HornetQ, etc.). This type of topology can be used for a simple event-processing flow that does not require central event orchestration. Now, let&rsquo;s pay attention to these topology components.

Click on the dots to learn more about broker topology components.

Broker topology consists of a broker component and an event processor component. The broker component can be centralized or federated and contains all event channels used within the event flow. As ypu already know, the event channels contained within the broker component can be message queues, message topics, or a combination of both.

Message queues, message topics, or a combination of both can serve as the event channels contained within the broker component. As a consequence of having no central event-mediator component that controls and orchestrates the initial event, each event-processor component assumes responsibility for processing an event and publishing a new event that reveals the action it has just executed.

Now, let&rsquo;s look at the scheme below. As you can see, there is no central event-mediator component that controls and orchestrates the initial event. Instead, each event-processor component is responsible for processing an event and publishing a new event indicating the action it has just performed.

For example, an event processor that balances a portfolio of stocks may receive an initial event called stock split. The event processor may do some portfolio rebalancing based on that initial event and then publish a new event to the broker called rebalance portfolio, which would then be picked up by a different event processor. Sometimes an event may be published by an event processor but not picked up by any another event processor. This is a common situation if you are evolving an application or providing for future functionality and extensions.

Broker Topology Example

To better illustrate broker topology, let&rsquo;s consider a similar scenario to the one provided in the Mediator Topology Example section. Let&rsquo;s take the workflow of an insurance company where a customer wants to change the address. In this example, there are two event processors that are interested in the change address event:&nbsp;the quote process and the claims process.

Click on the hot spots to overview the example.

After the customer has moved, an initiation event is created and will be handled by the customer processor.

The customer processor will go through the customer records and update the address.

Once updated, the customer process will post a message to a message queue for the other event processors. Those that are &lsquo;interested&rsquo; in address changes will &lsquo;listen&rsquo; and respond.

In this case, both the quote and claims processes are listening and will pick up this change address message from the message queue.

The quote processor will update the quotes and recalculate them on behalf of the customer. After that, it will send a message to the notification message queue.

Simultaneously, the claims process will handle the change of address message by updating claims. After that, it will post a message to the message queue for anyone interested in updated claims.

Both the notification and adjustment processors pick up this message and generate an email to the customer, indicating that all work has been done.

Loading drag and drop problem.

Pros and Cons

Quite often, only a part of the system or some of its components is built using the event-driven style. It has some significant advantages, but in general, it is relatively complex to implement. So, let&rsquo;s take a closer look at event-driven architecture&rsquo;s pros and cons.

Click on the flip cards to learn more about event-driven architecture advantages and downsides.

PROS

  • Loosely coupled architecture
  • Scalability and performance QAs can be achieved relatively easily
  • Overall, it&rsquo;s right from a deployment perspective because all is decoupled


CONS

    • Relatively complex to implement because of distributed components (event processors); it requires thinking about transactions (if necessary) and sync/async processing
    • Low testability and hard to debug
    • Managing events contracts (input and output data)

For the deep-dive into event-driven architecture, overview the main architectural examples provided in this article.

L4: Architectural Style. Actor-Based and Module-Based

Bookmark

Lesson Introduction

This lesson will provide information about the actor-based architectural style, its unique aspects, and cases when it is applicable. First developed in the early 1970s, this style has evolved over the years, but the fundamental concepts remained the same. Besides the general overview, you will learn the languages and frameworks it works with and examine some examples which will allow you to understand this style better. Moreover, you will familiarize yourself with module-based architecture and its main features.

Actor Model Overview

The actor model aims to deal with concurrent computations. It identifies standard rules that describe the required behavior of the system&rsquo;s components and their interaction. As a primitive unit of computation, an actor obtains a message and performs a kind of calculation based on it. This model&rsquo;s concept is akin to the object-oriented approach: an object obtains a message (a method call) and acts according to the message it has received (the method you are calling).

Click on the video to learn more about the actor and the actor model. Alternatively, you may click&nbsp;here to download a text script to find out what you will learn.

How Does the Actor-Based Model Work?

Actors send messages to each other. Sending a message does not transfer the thread of execution from the sender to the destination. An actor can send a message and continue without blocking. Therefore, it can accomplish more in the same amount of time. Let&rsquo;s figure out what happens when an actor receives a message.

Scroll to learn more.

First, the actor adds the message to the end of a queue.

If the actor was not scheduled for execution, it is marked as ready to execute.

A hidden scheduler entity takes the actor and starts executing it.

Then, the actor picks the message from the front of the queue.

The actor modifies the internal state and sends messages to other actors.

At this stage, the actor is
unscheduled.

Actors need to store messages somewhere while processing another message. The mailbox is the place where these messages are stored. There are several things you must keep in mind to move forward.

Although multiple actors can run simultaneously, each actor processes a message in sequence. There is no difference whether the actor you are sending a message to is running locally or in another node. If you consider an actor as a unit of code with a mailbox and internal state which only responds to the messages, it does not matter which machine it is running on. So, multiple computers can be used to recover when one of them fails.

Loading&hellip;

Ticket Counter Example

Let&rsquo;s revise the ticket counter scenario. In this example, the requestors are represented as customer actors. The ticket count is maintained with an actor, and it holds the current state of the counter. Both the customer and tickets actors do not hold threads when they have no messages to process.

To initiate a buy operation, a customer actor sends a buy message to a single tickets actor. Such buy messages contain the quantity to be purchased. When a tickets actor receives a buy message, it verifies that the purchase amount does not exceed the current remaining count. If the buy request is valid, the count is decremented, and the tickets actor sends a message to the customer actor indicating that the order has been accepted. If the buy amount exceeds the count, the counter actor sends the customer actor a message indicating that the order was rejected. In order to build a clearer understanding, let&rsquo;s examine this example step-by-step and pay attention to some visualizations.

Click on the step-by-step interactivity to explore the process described in the example.

In the following diagram, you can see a few customer actors, each sending a buy message to the tickets actor. These buy messages are initially queued in the tickets actor&rsquo;s mailbox.

The tickets actor processes each message. The diagram shows the first message, which is a request to buy five tickets.

The tickets actor checks that the buy amount does not exceed the remaining ticket count. In this case, the ticket count is currently 15, so the buy request is approved, the count is decremented, and a message is sent from the tickets actor to the requesting customer actor indicating that the tickets have been purchased.

The tickets actor processes each of the messages in its mailbox.

The following diagram shows how the tickets actor handles requests that exceed the remaining ticket count. You can see a request to buy two tickets when only one is available. The tickets actor rejects this purchase request and sends the requesting customer actor a sold-out message.

The actor-based implementation provides natural synchronization of operations within each actor and eliminates the potentially large backlog of threads waiting for their turn at the synchronized section. In the ticket example, each customer actor waits for a response without holding a thread.

Actor-Based Languages and Frameworks

There are several languages used in the actor-based architectural style. The main languages include Scala and Erlang, while the main frameworks refer to Akka, Orleans, and Vert.x. Now, let&rsquo;s have a more detailed look at each of them.

Click on the flip cards to learn more about the languages.


Scala

Scala is a general-purpose programming language providing support for functional programming and a strong static type system. Scala combines object-oriented and functional programming in one concise, high-level language. Designed to be concise, many of Scala&rsquo;s design decisions aim to address criticisms of Java.


Erlang

Erlang is a general-purpose, concurrent, functional programming language, and a garbage-collected runtime system. The term &ldquo;Erlang&rdquo; is used interchangeably with Erlang/OTP, or Open Telecom Platform (OTP), which consists of the Erlang runtime system, several ready-to-use components mainly written in Erlang, and a set of design principles for Erlang programs.

Now that you&rsquo;ve become familiar with common languages used when applying an actor-based architectural style, let&rsquo;s view additional information about the range of frameworks, which can also be helpful.

Click on the tabs to learn more about the frameworks.

Akka is a toolkit for building highly concurrent, distributed, and resilient message-driven applications for Java and Scala. Akka&rsquo;s use of the actor model provides a level of abstraction that makes it easier to write correct concurrent, parallel, and distributed systems. The actor model spans the full set of Akka libraries, providing you with a consistent way of understanding and using them. Thus, Akka offers a depth of integration you cannot achieve by picking libraries to solve individual problems and trying to piece them together.

Orleans is a cross-platform framework for building robust, scalable distributed applications. Orleans builds on the developer productivity of .NET and brings it to the world of distributed applications, such as cloud services. Implementation of Orleans is based on the Actor Model. However, unlike actors in more traditional actor systems (e.g., Akka), Orleans grains are virtual actors. The biggest difference is that the physical instantiations of grains are completely abstracted away and are automatically managed by the Orleans runtime.

Eclipse Vert.x is a tool-kit for building reactive (scalable as workloads grow, and resilient when failures arise) applications on the JVM. It is backed by a large ecosystem of reactive modules with just all you need to write modern services. Vert.x comes with a simple, scalable, actor-like deployment and concurrency model out of the box that you can use to save you writing your own. The model does not claim to be a strict actor-model implementation, but it does share similarities, especially with respect to concurrency, scaling, and deployment.

Use Case: Orleans for Halo 4 Videogame

Let&rsquo;s consider an example of Orleans usage. This framework has been used to build and run multiple cloud services by different teams, including all cloud services for the Halo 4 videogame. There are several services made for two separate games. Those services used Orleans to implement different parts of the game backend logic with distinctly different usage patterns and performance characteristics.

Click on the dropdowns to learn more.

The Presence service is responsible for keeping track of all active game sessions, participating players, and evolving game status. It enhances players&rsquo; matchmaking experience, allows them to join an active game, enables real-time viewing of a game session, and other functionality.

The structure of the Presence service is shown in the diagram. There are three types of actors: Router, Game Session, and Player. Incoming heartbeat requests from consoles are delivered to the Router actor, which decompresses the data, extracts the session ID, and forwards the request to the right Session actor. There is one Game Session actor for every session ID. The Session actor updates its internal in-memory state, and periodically, but not on every heartbeat, calls Player actors using the player IDs extracted from the heartbeat data. Player actors also serve as rendezvous points for an external observer, such as a mobile phone companion application, for finding the current game session for a given user.

Statistics service processes results of completed and in-progress games with details of important events, such as successful shots, weapons used, locations of events on the map, etc.

This diagram shows a simplified architecture of the Statistics service. The front-end server that receives an HTTP request with a statistics data payload saves the data in the Azure Service Bus reliable queue. A separate set of worker processes pull the requests from the queue and call the corresponding Game Session actors using the session ID as the actor identity. Orleans routes this call to the Game Session actor&rsquo;s activation, instantiating a new one if necessary. The Game Session actor first saves the payload as-is to the Azure BLOB store, then unpacks it and sends relevant pieces to Player actors of the players listed in the game statistics. Each Player actor then processes its part and writes the results to the Azure Table store. That data is later used for serving queries about the player&rsquo;s status, accomplishments, etc.

There is also one more service called Galactic Reign Service. It uses four types of actors: stateful Game Session and stateless Video Manager, Housekeeper, and Notification actors.

If you&rsquo;d like to learn how it works, pay attention to this article, page 9.

Actor Model Use Cases

Now, when you know how exactly the actor model works, let&rsquo;s discover where it can be effectively applied. The actor model can be used as a framework for modeling, understanding, and reasoning about a wide range of concurrent systems.

Click on the dots to overview how the actor model can be used.

Electronic Mail

Electronic mail can be modeled as an actor system. In such cases, accounts are modeled as actors, and email addresses are modeled as actor addresses.

Web Services

One more use case refers to web services. They can be modeled with Simple Object Access Protocol (SOAP) endpoints, which are modeled as actor addresses.

Objects With Locks

Objects with locks (e.g., as in Java and C#) can be modeled as a serializer, provided that their implementations are such that messages can continually arrive.

Testing and Test Control Notation

The actor model is followed by Testing and Test Control Notation, both TTCN-2 and TTCN-3. In TTCN actor is a test component: either the parallel test component (PTC) or the main test component (MTC).

Module-Based Architecture

Modular Architecture, as a style, not only helps to view the system in layers or services but goes one level below as a composition of smaller, physical modules. The keywords you should be aware of when considering module-based architecture are &ldquo;modularity&rdquo; and &ldquo;module&rdquo;.

Click on the flip cards to become familiar with modules and modularity.


Modularity

Modularity is a design principle that helps achieve: loose coupling between components; clear contracts and dependencies between components; hidden implementation using strong encapsulation. In a computer-science sense, modularity is when your software application&rsquo;s code is divided into logical parts representing separate concerns.


Module

The module can be defined as a &ldquo;deployable, manageable, natively reusable, composable, stateless unit of software that provides a concise interface to consumers.&rdquo; If you consider Java, a JAR file represents the essence of a module.

A module has a name and a version. It also declares all required dependencies, has a clear business context, encloses the physical layer, works within the context provided, and expresses its scope through a public interface. Modules help understand, extend, and manage the system during the design process and during run time. These processes are called design-time modularity and run-time modularity, respectively. The scheme below illustrates the module-based architecture.

The focus of modular architecture is on how you design the physical composition of the application.

Why Should You Care About Modularity?

Investing in software modularity has many benefits, but it&rsquo;s basically about providing rapidness and flexibility. Fast and frequent development of new features allows you to provide your customer with new software and hardware products they need. You can maintain quality and product reliability while continuously releasing new features. In an integrated or monolithic architecture, there&rsquo;s a risk that when you introduce a new feature update, the whole product goes down. Even if the update feature is small, like a nice new Graphical User Interface (GUI), customers can be afraid to update if it&rsquo;s a part of a big monolithic package. For many companies, the customers&rsquo; reservations about updating have been a real issue. Modular architecture allows you to speed up the development pace, minimize bugs, provide more time for testing issues and release. You&rsquo;re also forced to use old and expensive hardware and run end-of-life hardware projects, often in panic mode. The benefits of modular architecture can be visualized using a traffic metaphor.

Swipe the illustration to the right to see the graphic representation of monolithic software architecture and to the left to view a an image of modular software architecture.

Open Services Gateway Initiative

The OSGi Service Platform is the industry standard defined by the OSGi Alliance to specifically address the lack of support for modularity in the Java platform. As a continuation of its modularity support, it introduces a service-oriented programming model, referred to by some as SOA in a VM, to help you clearly separate interface from implementation. OSGi is a modularity layer for the Java platform. OSGi provides you with several benefits, so let&rsquo;s learn more about them.

Scroll to learn more about several different opportunities provided by OSGi.

OSGi provides you with an opportunity of packaging an application as logically independent JAR files and deploying only the pieces you need for a given installation. This pretty much describes the purpose of OSGi.

Packaging an application as independent JAR files, declaring which code is accessible from each JAR file, and having this visibility enforced. OSGi enables a new level of code visibility for JAR files so you can specify what is visible externally.

Defining an extensibility mechanism for an application, like a plugin mechanism. OSGi modularity is particularly suited to providing a powerful extensibility mechanism, including support for execution-time dynamism.

Execution-time errors from your application due to the wrong version of a dependent library on the class path. OSGi verifies that the set of dependencies is consistent with respect to required versions and other constraints.

Jigsaw Project

Project Jigsaw is an umbrella project with new features aimed at two aspects: the introduction of the module system in the Java language and its implementation in JDK source and Java runtime. This project&rsquo;s primary motivations are to create a module system for the language, apply it to the JDK source, modularize the JDK libraries, update the runtime to support modularity, and provide the opportunity to create smaller runtime with a subset of modules from JDK.

Click on the hot spots to learn about modularity tools.

It helps in analyzing the codebase to identify the dependencies on JDK APIs and the third-party JARs. It also mentions the name of the module where the JDK API can be found. This makes it easier to modularize the codebase

It helps in analyzing the codebase for the usage of any deprecated APIs

It helps in creating a smaller runtime by combining the application&rsquo;s and the JDK&rsquo;s modules

It helps in working with jmod files. jmod is a new format for packaging the modules. This format allows including native code, configuration files, and other data that do not fit into JAR files

This lesson was focused on the actor-based architectural style, its key characteristics, purpose, applicable languages, and frameworks. Also, you examined the main concept and benefits of the module-based architecture. Now you can differentiate two explained styles clearly and use them in solution development.

L5: Architectural Style. REST

Bookmark

Lesson Introduction

In the following lesson, you will get acquainted with the Representational State Transfer or REST architectural style and learn how to design web-services using its paradigms. You will gain an understanding of the general approach, as well as the Richardson maturity model and the key constraint of the REST application architecture. Diagrams included in the lesson will help you visualize information and make it easier to master it.

REST Formal Constraints

Representational State Transfer or REST is a software architectural style that makes it easier for systems to communicate with each other and defines a set of constraints to use for creating web services. This style is often used in the development of web services. REST-compliant systems are characterized by their statelessness and how they separate the client and server&rsquo;s concerns.

REST term was coined by Roy Fielding in 2000. REST does not enforce any rule regarding how it should be implemented at a lower level. It just puts high-level design guidelines and lets you think of your own implementation. REST defines six architectural constraints that make any web service a truly RESTful API.

Click on the dots to learn more about constraints.

Client-Server

Client-Server. The REST style separates clients from a server. This basically means that client and server applications should develop individually and have no dependency on each other. Whether the issue is with the server or the client side, things should flow naturally since there is no coupling between them. The client side should not care about data storage, and the server side should not care about the interface at all. A client should be aware only of resource URIs. Today, this can be considered a standard practice in web development, so nothing extraordinary is required from your side.

Stateless

Stateless. The data from the client&rsquo;s latest HTTP request is not stored on the server, and each request is treated as a new one. There is no session and no history. The client application is required to be a stateful application for the end user, meaning that the user logs in once to perform other authorized operations. All information essential to service the request should be included in each request from the client and contain authentication and authorization details. After the server handles the request, the state changes, and it gets sent back to the requestor with the appropriate HTTP status code.

Cacheable

Cacheable. Caching allows improving the client side&rsquo;s performance and simplifying the server&rsquo;s scope and scalability due to a load reduction. In REST, it can be used for resources when applicable, and these resources are required to declare themselves as cacheable. Caching aims never to have to generate the same response more than once. The request flows through a cache or a series of caches in front of the service hosting the resource. If any of them match any criteria during the request (e.g., the timestamp or the client ID), the data is returned based on the cache layer, and if the caches cannot satisfy the request, the request goes to the server.

Layered System

Layered system. REST provides an opportunity to use a layered system architecture. Within this approach, the APIs are deployed on Server A, data is stored on Server B, and requests are authenticated on Server C. Under usual circumstances, the client can&rsquo;t tell if it is connected directly to the end server or to an intermediary one. For instance, when you need to scale a service, you might use a proxy working as a load balancer&mdash;that way, the incoming requests are deliverable to the appropriate server instance. The client side does not need to understand how the server works; it just makes requests to the same URI.

(Optional) Code-On-Demand

Code-on-demand. This constraint is the only optional constraint in the REST style. Mainly static representations of resources are sent in XML or JSON format. In summary, a code-on-demand pattern means that the server can add more functionality to the REST client by sending code that can be executable by that client. It allows the executable code to be returned to support a part of the application, if necessary. For example, to receive a UI widget rendering code, clients can call your API. It is permitted. The constraint says that this strategy improves scalability since the code can execute the server independently on the client side.

Uniform Interface

Uniform interface. This constraint describes a contract between clients and servers. A resource in the system is required to have only one logical URI. It must ensure a way of getting related or additional information. It is recommended to synonymize a resource with a web page. Each resource shouldn&rsquo;t be too large or include everything in its representation. Where applicable, a resource has to contain links to correspondent URIs to receive related information. Once there is a contract aligned with the client and server parts, they can start their works independently. The way that they will communicate is firmly based on the interface.

Please follow the&nbsp;link to read more about REST.

Now, when you have familiarized yourself with the main constraints, let&rsquo;s figure out how the general approach to REST style can be illustrated and observe the diagram below. It contains key components and interrelations between them.

Move the pieces of the diagram below to rebuild the scheme. Click on the piece you want to move, and then on the piece you want to be replaced with the first one.

HTTP Methods

REST guidelines suggest using a specific HTTP method for a particular type of call made to the server (though technically it is possible to violate this guideline, yet it is highly discouraged). Let&rsquo;s examine some information that can help find a suitable HTTP method for API action.

Click on the tabs to learn about the most widely used HTTP methods.

GET requests should be used to retrieve resource representation/information only &ndash; and not to modify it in any way. As GET requests do not change the state of the resource, these are said to be safe methods. Note that GET APIs should be idempotent, which means that making multiple identical requests must produce the same result every time until another API (POST or PUT) changes the resource&rsquo;s state on the server.

Example request URIs:

  • HTTP GET http://www.appdomain.com/users
  • HTTP GET http://www.appdomain.com/users?size=20&amp;page=5

Use POST APIs to create new subordinate resources. For example, a file is subordinate to a directory containing it, or a row is subordinate to a database table. POST methods are used to create a new resource into the collection of resources. If a resource has been created on the origin server, the response SHOULD be HTTP response code 201 (Created) and contain an entity that describes the request&rsquo;s status and refers to the new resource.

Example request URIs:

  • HTTP POST http://www.appdomain.com/users
  • HTTP POST http://www.appdomain.com/users/123/accounts

PUT APIs are primarily used to update an existing resource (if the resource does not exist, then API may decide whether to create a new one or not). If the PUT API has created a new resource, the origin server MUST inform the user agent via the HTTP response code 201(Created) response. If an existing resource is modified, either the 200 (OK) or 204 (No Content) response codes SHOULD be sent to indicate successful completion of the request.

Example request URIs:

  • HTTP PUT http://www.appdomain.com/users/123
  • HTTP PUT http://www.appdomain.com/users/123/accounts/456

Use DELETE to delete resources (identified by the Request-URI). A successful response of DELETE requests SHOULD be HTTP response code 200 (OK) if the response includes an entity describing the status, 202 (Accepted) if the action has been queued, or 204 (No Content) if the action has been performed, but the response does not include an entity. If you DELETE a resource, it&rsquo;s removed from the collection of resources.

Example request URIs:

  • HTTP DELETE http://www.appdomain.com/users/123
  • HTTP DELETE http://www.appdomain.com/users/123/accounts/456

Refer&nbsp;here for additional information about HTTP Methods.

Richardson Model Overview and Example

Leonard Richardson is an expert on RESTful API design. Richardson Maturity Model was developed to help explain the specific properties of a system. The model can be helpful when thinking about using different techniques.

Click on the video to learn more about the Richardson model. Alternatively, you may click&nbsp;here to download a text script to find out what you will learn.

As you&rsquo;ve figured out, the Richardson model breaks down the key elements of the Representational State Transfer approach into several steps. Now, let&rsquo;s overview each of these steps in detail.

Click at the step-by-step interactivity to learn more about the mentioned layers.

Level 0

Essentially, what is done at this stage is using HTTP as a tunneling mechanism for your own remote interaction mechanism, usually based on Remote Procedure Invocation. Let&rsquo;s consider an example suggested by Martin Fowler. Assume you want to book an appointment with your doctor. First, the appointment software needs to know what open slots the doctor can provide on a given date. It makes a request to the hospital appointment system to obtain that information. In a level 0 scenario, the hospital will expose a service endpoint at some URI. Then you post a document containing the request&rsquo;s details to that endpoint, and the server returns a document with the requested information. The next step is to book an appointment, which can be done by posting the document to the endpoint. In case of success, a response saying the appointment is booked is received. If there is a problem (someone else booked it before you), then you&rsquo;ll get an error message in the reply body.

Level 1: Resources

At this stage, rather than making all the requests to a singular service endpoint, you can start talking to individual resources. With the initial query, you might have a resource for the given doctor. The reply carries the same necessary information, but each slot is now a resource that can be addressed individually. With specific resources booking an appointment means posting to a particular slot. If it goes right, you get a similar reply. The difference is that if the appointment needs to be (i.e., to book additional tests), first you need to obtain the appointment resource, which might have a URI like http://royalhope.nhs.uk/slots/1234/appointment. After that, you can post to this resource.

Level 2: HTTP Verbs

Level 2 uses the HTTP verbs as closely as possible to how they are used in HTTP itself. For the list of slots, this means using GET (the use of GET for a request like this is crucial).

GET /doctors/mjones/slots?date=20100104&amp;status=open HTTP/1.1 
Host: royalhope.nhs.uk

To book an appointment, you need an HTTP verb that changes state; for example, a POST or a PUT. If it succeeds, the service replies with a response code of 201 to indicate that there&rsquo;s a new resource. The 201 response includes a location attribute with a URI that the client can use to GET the current state of that resource in the future. There is also a difference if something goes wrong. Let&rsquo;s imagine that someone else has booked the session. In this case, a 409 (conflict) seems the right choice to indicate that someone else has already updated the resource in an incompatible way.

Level 3: Hypermedia Controls

As was mentioned in the video, the final level introduces the HATEOAS (Hypertext As The Engine Of Application State) acronym. You can begin with the same GET that you have received in Level 2. This time the response has a new element: each slot now has a link element that contains a URI to tell how to book an appointment. Hypermedia controls tell what can be done next and the URI of the resource you need to manipulate to do it. In this case, the response to your POST will contain several hypermedia controls for different things to do next.

For a more detailed overview of this example and code samples, refer here.

HATEOAS Example

As you already know, HATEOAS means that hypertext should be used to find your way through the API. Let&rsquo;s learn more about HATEOAS introduced in the previous block and consider an example. A REST client enters a REST application through a simple fixed URL. All future actions the client may take are discovered within the resource representations returned from the server. The media types used for these representations and the link relations they may contain are standardized. User transitions through the application states by selecting from the links within a representation or by manipulating the representation in other ways allowed by its media type. In this way, RESTful interaction is driven by hypermedia rather than out-of-band information.

Click on the dropdown to see the example.

This GET request fetches an account resource requesting details in a JSON representation.

GET /accounts/12345 HTTP/1.1
Host: bank.example.com
Accept: application/vnd.acme.account+json
...

Apart from the statement that there are 100 dollars (US) in the account, the received response includes several possible follow-up links: make a deposit, withdrawal, or transfer; close the account. The "link" tags allow to find the URLs needed for the specified actions.

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Type: application/vnd.acme.account+json
Content-Length: ...
{
    "account": {
        "account_number": 12345,
        "balance": {
            "currency": "usd",
            "value": 100.00
        },
        "links": {
            "deposit": "/accounts/12345/deposit",
            "withdraw": "/accounts/12345/withdraw",
            "transfer": "/accounts/12345/transfer",
            "close": "/accounts/12345/close"
        }
    }
}

When the account information is retrieved, the account is overdrawn. Now you are 25 dollars in the red. You can only deposit money, and you don&rsquo;t have access to other options. As long as you are in the red, the account cannot be closed; it is not possible to transfer or withdraw any money . The hypertext is telling what is allowed and what is not.

HTTP/1.1 200 OK
Content-Type: application/vnd.acme.account+json
Content-Length: ...

{
    "account": {
        "account_number": 12345,
        "balance": {
            "currency": "usd",
            "value": -25.00
        },
        "links": {
            "deposit": "/accounts/12345/deposit"
        }
    }
}

Follow the&nbsp;link to find more information regarding&nbsp;HATEOAS Driven REST APIs.

REST Architecture Style Best Practices

Now, let&rsquo;s examine how to design REST APIs to be easy to understand for anyone consuming them, future-proof, fast, and secure since they may be used to serve confidential data to the clients. For this reason, there are numerous ways for a networked application to break. It should be guaranteed that REST APIs handle errors gracefully using standard HTTP codes.

Scroll to explore the best practices for creating REST APIs.

Accept and Respond
with JSON

REST APIs should accept JSON for request payload and send responses to JSON. JSON is the standard for transferring data. Almost every networked technology can use it: JavaScript has built-in methods to encode and decode JSON either through the Fetch API or another HTTP client. Server-side technologies have libraries that can decode JSON without doing much work.

Nouns Instead of Verbs in
Endpoint Paths

Your HTTP request method already has the verb, so use the nouns representing the entity that you are retrieving or manipulating as the pathname. Keep in mind, that you should create routes like GET /articles/ for getting news articles. Likewise, POST /articles/ is for adding a new article, etc.

Naming Collections with
Plural Nouns

Unless you want to retrieve a single item, you should use plural nouns. Tables usually have more than one entry and are named to reflect that, so to be consistent with them, you should use the same language as the table the API accesses. With the /articles endpoint, you have the plural form for all endpoints, so you do not need to change it.

Nesting Resources for
Hierarchical Objects

For the endpoints' path that deals with nested resources, append the nested resource as the name of the path that comes after the parent resource. What you consider a nested resource should match what you have in the database tables. If you want an endpoint to get the comments for a news article, append the /comments path to the end of the /articles path.

Graceful Error Handling and
Standard Error Codes

To eliminate confusion for API users when an error occurs, you should handle errors gracefully and return HTTP response codes that indicate what kind of an error occurred. This gives API maintainers enough information to understand the problem. Prevent the errors that could bring down your system, and don&rsquo;t leave them unhandled.

Filtering, Sorting,
and Pagination

The databases behind a REST API can get very large. It can get to the point that the data should not be returned all at once because it slows the system or even brings it down. Items should be filtered. Also, data should be paginated so that only a few results at a time are returned. The usage of server resources can be reduced significantly by filtering and paginating.

Maintain Good
Security Practices

Most communication between the client and the server must be private. People should not be able to access more information than they requested. For example, a user should not be able to access the data of another user. To enforce the principle of least privilege, you need to add role checks for a single role or have more granular roles for each user.

Cache Data to Improve
Performance

To return data from the local memory cache, you can add caching. This will help you prevent querying the database to retrieve the data upon a user&rsquo;s request. With caching, users can get data faster. Make sure that the data is up-to-date. There are caching solutions like Redis, in-memory caching, etc. Change the way data is cached as the needs change.

Versioning the
APIs

You should have different versions of API if you want to make any changes that could negatively affect your clients. The versioning can be done according to semantic version (e.g., 2.0.6 to indicate a major version two and the sixth patch) like most apps do nowadays. This way, you can gradually phase out old endpoints instead of forcing everyone to move to the new API at the same time.

Refer&nbsp;here if you want to know more.

Is REST the Best Fit for All Scenarios?

REST is the right style to use for most applications. It has an active tooling community and developers are generally comfortable with it. REST is applicable for many use cases. However, there are some exceptions. According to Henric Stene, REST is a good fit for any of the traditional use cases, but there are other technologies that will help &lsquo;supercharge&rsquo; APIs and make them better.

Thibault Ducret specifies three distinct areas where REST is not the best option. They include messaging, internal microservices, and performance with GraphQL and gRPC.

Click on the flip cards to learn more about these areas.




Messaging

Messaging-style APIs aren&rsquo;t a good fit for REST because they force users to do constant polling. According to T. Ducret, the architecture should be designed around the Publish-subscribe pattern and implemented through the web socket protocol.




Internal microservices

Another instance where REST is insufficient is when you break apart a monolith and have microservices that must communicate with each other. In this scenario, &ldquo;you may be tempted to replace function calls of the monolithic application with synchronous REST API requests,&rdquo; said Thibault. This creates a series of sequential API requests, essentially perpetuating the monolith.



Performance with GraphQl

REST isn&rsquo;t the best option if high performance is critical for users. In REST, developers are unable to call multiple resources with a single API call or retrieve only the properties the client requires. For these scenarios, GraphQL can be a more elegant option. Alternatively, other options include adding a fields query parameter or using an optimized (but less readable) payload like gRPC.

Lesson Summary

After completing this lesson, you&rsquo;ve become aware of what the Representational State Transfer architectural style is and why the REST-compliant systems can be more beneficial for specific services on the web. You have also reviewed a Richardson maturity model and hypermedia as the Engine of Application State, which is a constraint for the REST application architecture.
