L6: Architectural Patterns. Performance and Scalability

Bookmark

Lesson Introduction

When you design software architecture for a complete system, you need to make sure it will accommodate additional sets of requirements beyond the basics. Performance and scalability are essential quality attributes that require particular attention. The following lesson will focus on architectural patterns that help manage potential challenges regarding the system&rsquo;s ability to deal with an increased number of users and execute any action within a given time interval.

Performance and Scalability Patterns

There are three most frequently used performance and scalability patterns: Command and Query Responsibility Segregation (CQRS), Event Sourcing pattern, and Sharding patterns. Let&rsquo;s view them in detail and dive deep into the context they are used in, problems they deal with, and optimal solutions.

Traditional CRUD Architecture

The acronym CRUD, which stands for Create, Read, Update and Delete, is the standardized use of HTTP Action Verbs. In traditional architectures, the same data model is used to query and update a database, as shown in the diagram. It is simple and works well for basic CRUD operations. However, in more complex applications, this approach can become unwieldy and lead to several downsides.

For example, the application may perform many different queries on the read side, returning data transfer objects (DTOs) with different shapes. This can complicate object mapping. As for the write side, the model may implement complex validation and business logic. This can result in an overly complicated model, trying to do too much. Read and write workloads usually have different performance and scale requirements and are asymmetrical. Now, let&rsquo;s learn more about CRUD disadvantages.

Click on the flip cards to learn more about these disadvantages.


Mismatch Between the Read and Write Representations

There is often a discrepancy between the read and write representations of the data. For example, additional columns or properties that must be correctly updated even though they aren&rsquo;t a part of an operation.



Data Contention and Update Conflicts

Data contention can be caused by locking the records in the data store in a collaborative domain, where multiple actors operate in parallel on the same set of data. Also, update conflicts can be attributable to concurrent updates with optimistic locking. As the system&rsquo;s complexity and throughput grow, the risks increase with them. The traditional approach can harm performance due to load on the data store and data access layer and the complexity of queries required to retrieve information.


Complexity in Managing
Security

Each entity is subject to read and write operations, making managing security and permissions more complicated and exposing data in the wrong context.

Command and Query Responsibility Segregation (CQRS) Pattern

Let&rsquo;s focus on the Command and Query Responsibility Segregation (CQRS) pattern, explore it in detail, and dive deep into the context it is used in, problems it deals with, and how it can be applied to resolve these problems effectively.

Click on the hot spots to learn more about each aspect.

Context/Risk. As a rule, all create, read, update, and delete (CRUD) operations may be used in the same representation of the entity. However, as previously mentioned, this approach has several disadvantages.

Intention. Data should be divided into separate physical stores to perform read and write operations, and eventual consistency between data stores must be supported.

Solution. Utilizing separate interfaces segregate read data from update data operations.

Command and Query Responsibility Segregation Pattern

The Command and Query Responsibility Segregation (CQRS) pattern separates read and update operations for a data store. Implementing CQRS in your application can maximize its performance, scalability, and security. The flexibility created by migrating to CQRS allows a system to evolve better over time and prevents update commands from causing merge conflicts at the domain level. Let&rsquo;s figure out how exactly the described pattern can be used to overcome the abovementioned limitations of traditional CRUD architecture.

Click on the dots to learn more.

CQRS helps separate reads and writes into different models using commands to update data and queries to read data. Rather than being data-centric, commands should be task-based. For example, you should use &ldquo;Book hotel room&rdquo; instead of &ldquo;set ReservationStatus to Reserved&rdquo;. Commands may be placed on a queue for asynchronous processing rather than being processed synchronously. Queries never modify the database. A query returns a DTO that does not encapsulate any domain knowledge. The models can then be isolated although it&rsquo;s not an indispensable requirement.

For better isolation, you can physically set the read data apart from the write data. In this case, the read database can use its own data schema optimized for queries. For example, it can store a materialized view of the data to avoid complex joins or complex O/RM mappings. If you choose to use separated read and write databases, they must be kept in sync. Usually, this is accomplished by having the write model publish an event whenever it updates the database. Updating the database and publishing the event must occur in a single transaction.

CQRS Use-Cases

There are several scenarios where you can use the Command and Query Responsibility Segregation (CQRS) pattern effectively. However, in some cases applying this pattern should be avoided. Let&rsquo;s have a look at the good and bad use cases of CQRS.

Scroll to learn more about scenarios where CQRS can be applied effectively.

Collaborative domains where many users access the same data in parallel. CQRS allows you to define commands with enough granularity to minimize merge conflicts at the domain level.

Scenarios with task-based user interfaces where users are guided through a complex process as a series of steps or with complex domain
models.

Scenarios where data reads performance must be fine-tuned separately from the performance of data writes, particularly when the number of reads is much higher than the number of writes.

Scenarios where one team of developers can focus on the complex domain model that is part of the write model, and another team can concentrate on the read model and the user interfaces.

Scenarios where the system is expected to evolve over time and might contain multiple versions of the model, or where business rules change regularly.

Integration with other systems, especially in combination with Event Sourcing, where one subsystem&rsquo;s temporal failure shouldn&rsquo;t affect the availability of the others.

At the same time, this pattern isn&rsquo;t recommended when the domain or the business rules are simple, and when a simple CRUD-style user interface and data access operations are sufficient. In some cases, CQRS can be replaced with a Reporting Database. Now, let&rsquo;s examine this pattern&rsquo;s strengths and learn more about when it should not be used.

Click on the video to learn more about CQRS. Alternatively, you may click&nbsp;here to download a text script to find out what you will learn.

The benefits of CQRS are summarized here.

Loading&hellip;

Event Sourcing Description

Event Sourcing ensures that all changes to the application state are stored as a sequence of events. The event log can be used to reconstruct past states and as a foundation to adjust the state to cope with retroactive changes automatically. Let&rsquo;s examine which problems Event Sourcing is aimed to solve and how exactly this can be achieved.

Click on the flip cards to learn more about these aspects.




Context/Risk

The majority of applications working with data use the usual approach meaning that the application supports the current state of data making updates as far as users work with it. It may result in poor performance and slow responsiveness caused by conflicts, history loss, and requisite to process it overhead.

&rsaquo;



Intention

The intention is to support events consistency and provide practical ways of retrieving the object&rsquo;s current state.

&rsaquo;


Solution

Introduce an approach to handle operations on the data driven by a sequence of events. Each of these events is recorded in an append-only store that acts as the record system (the authoritative data source) for the data&rsquo;s current state.

How does Event Sourcing Work?

Now that you have discovered which problems Event Sourcing is aimed to solve, let&rsquo;s figure out how exactly this pattern works. As you already know, the Event Sourcing pattern defines an approach to handling data operations driven by a sequence of events, and each of them is recorded in an append-only store.

Click on the step-by-step interactivity to overview this process.

A series of events, which imperatively identifies each action that occurred on the data, is sent to the event store by the application code. Each event describes changes made to the data.

An event store where the events are persisted serves as the system of records (the authoritative data source) that provides details about the current state of data. The event store usually publishes these events to notify the consumers and handle them if needed. E.g., consumers could initiate tasks that apply the operations in the events to other systems or execute any other associated action that&rsquo;s required to complete the operation.

The events published by the event store are usually used to maintain materialized views of entities as actions in the application change them, and for their integration with external systems. For example, a system can maintain a materialized view of all customer orders that used to populate parts of the UI.

Applications can read the history of events at any point. This history can be used to materialize the entity&rsquo;s current state by playing back and consuming all the events related to that entity.

The figure shows an overview of the pattern, including some of the options for using the event stream, such as creating a materialized view, integrating events with external applications and systems, and replaying events to create projections of the current state of a specific entity.

Move the pieces of the diagram below in order to rebuild it. Click on the piece you want to move, and then on the piece you want to be replaced with the first one.

Event Sourcing Use Cases

Same as any other architectural pattern, Event Sourcing has its own good and bad use cases. Let&rsquo;s start with seven key situations when the Event Sourcing pattern is the most corresponding and continue with the scenarios where this pattern should be avoided.

Click on the dots to figure out when to use Event Sourcing.

When you need to understand the intent, goal, and reason in data. For example, you can track changes to a customer entity as a set of specific event types such as &ldquo;moved home&rdquo;, &ldquo;closed account&rdquo;, or &ldquo;deceased&rdquo;.

When you need to register events that arise and respond to them to restore the state of the system, roll back changes or track the history and audit log.

When working with events is considered a basic feature of the application&rsquo;s operation and needs minor efforts for additional development and implementation.

When decoupling of input and output data processes is required. For example, when you need to improve UI performance or to distribute events to other listeners that perform their functions when the event arises.

When you need the flexibility to change the format of materialized models and entity data in case of requirements changes and when combined with CQRS to adjust a read model or the views exposing the data.

In combination with CQRS, when eventual consistency is acceptable and a read model is updated. It can be used when the performance impact of rehydrating entities and data from an event stream are tolerable.

Finally, the Event Sourcing pattern can be effectively applied in scenarios when it is crucial to minimize or prevent conflicting updates to data.

With all the scenarios where the Event Sourcing pattern fits the need, there are several situations where it might not be useful. Let&rsquo;s move to the next interactivity to build an understanding of when you should avoid using this pattern.

Scroll to figure out when not to use Event Sourcing.

Small or simple domains and systems that have little or no business logic.

Non-domain systems that work well with traditional CRUD data management mechanisms.

Systems where consistency and real-time updates to the views of the data are required.

Systems where audit trails, history, and capabilities to roll back and replay actions are not required.

Systems where there&rsquo;s only a very low occurrence of the updates conflicting with the underlying data.

Loading drag and drop problem.

Event Sourcing Example

Let&rsquo;s consider the next example. A conference management system has to track the number of completed bookings for a conference. It checks whether there are seats still available when a potential attendee tries to make a booking. The total number of bookings for a conference can be stored in at least two ways.

Click on the tabs to overview these ways.

The system could store information about the total number of bookings as a separate entity in a database that holds booking information. As bookings are made or canceled, the system could increment or decrement this number as appropriate. This approach can cause scalability issues if a large number of attendees are trying to book seats in a short period of time (e.g., on the last day or so prior to the booking period closing).

The system could store information about bookings and cancellations as events held in an event store. It could then calculate the number of seats available by replaying these events. This approach can be more scalable due to the immutability of events. The system only needs to be able to read or append data to the event store. Event information about bookings and cancellations is never modified.

The diagram below illustrates how you can implement the seat reservation subsystem of the conference management system using Event Sourcing. Let&rsquo;s overview this process more in detail and pay attention to the sequence of actions for reserving two seats.

Click on the hot spots to learn more.

The user interface issues a command to reserve seats for two attendees. A separate command handler handles this command. A piece of logic decoupled from the user interface is responsible for handling requests posted as commands.

An aggregate containing information about all reservations is constructed by querying the events that describe bookings and cancellations. This aggregate is called SeatAvailability, and is contained within a domain model that exposes methods for querying and modifying the aggregate data.

The command handler invokes a method exposed by the domain model to make the reservations.

The SeatAvailability aggregate records an event containing the number of seats that were reserved. The next time the aggregate applies events, all the reservations will be used to compute how many seats remain.

The system appends the new event to the list of events in the event store.

If a user decides to cancel a seat, the system follows a similar process. However, in this case, the command handler issues a command that generates a seat cancellation event and appends it to the event store.

If you want to know more about Event sourcing read here.

The benefits of Event Sourcing are summarized here.

Sharding Pattern

Dividing the data store into horizontal partitions or shards became convenient in a wide variety of use cases. Each shard has the same schema but holds its own distinct subset of the data. A shard is a kind of a data store since it can contain the data for many entities of different types. This shard is running on a server acting as a storage node. Now, let&rsquo;s overview the main aspects of the Sharding pattern.

Click on the step-by-step interactivity to learn more about the Sharding pattern.

Context/Risk

A data store hosted by a single server can be limited in one of the following ways:

  • Storage space. The system will eventually reach a limit where increasing the storage capacity on a given server isn&rsquo;t easily achieved.
  • Computing resources. A single server hosting the data store might not be sufficient to provide the necessary computing power in order to support this load, resulting in extended response times for users and frequent failures.
  • Network bandwidth. The volume of network traffic might exceed the network&rsquo;s capacity used to connect to the server, which can result in failed requests.
  • Geography. If the users are dispersed across different countries or regions, storing the entire application&rsquo;s data in a single data store might not be possible.

The effects of some limitations can be postponed by scaling vertically and adding more disk capacity, processing power, memory, and network connections. However, it&rsquo;s likely only a temporary solution.

Intention

Store data in the most effective way in terms of performance, cost, and location.

Solution

You can divide a data store into a set of horizontal partitions or shards. Doing this can improve scalability when storing and accessing large volumes of data. When dividing a data store up into shards, you must decide which data should be placed in each shard. Splitting the data in the way appropriate for the types of queries that the application performs is essential in order to ensure optimal performance and scalability.

Sharding Strategies

If you intend to divide a data store into shards, you should decide which data must be placed in each shard. Items aligned with a specific range defined by one or more data attributes usually comprise one shard. A shard key&mdash;sometimes called a partition key&mdash;is composed of these attributes. A shard key is typically static and based on changeable data. To choose a shard key and decide how to divide data across shards, you can use one of three commonly used strategies.

Click on the dropdowns to overview these strategies.

In this strategy, the sharding logic implements a map that routes a request for data to the shard containing that data by using the shard key. In a multi-tenant application, all the tenant data might be stored together in a shard using the tenant ID as a shard key. Multiple tenants might share the same shard, but the data for a single tenant won&rsquo;t be spread across various shards. The figure illustrates sharding tenant data based on tenant IDs.

This strategy allows you to control how shards are configured and used. When data is being rebalanced, applying virtual shards weakens impact as new physical partitions may be added to even out the workload. You can modify the mapping between a virtual shard and the physical partitions that implement the shard without affecting the application code, which uses a shard key to store and retrieve data.

In the range strategy, related items are grouped together in the same shard and ordered by a shard key. It&rsquo;s useful for applications that frequently retrieve sets of items using range queries (queries that return a set of data items for a shard key that falls within a given range). If an application regularly needs to find every order in a given month, this data could be retrieved more quickly if all orders for a chosen month are stored in date and time order in the same shard. If each order were stored in a different shard, you would need to perform a large number of point queries (queries that return a single data item) to fetch each of them individually.

In the illustrated example, the shard key is a composite key containing the order month as its most significant element, followed by the order day and the time. When new orders are created, the data for orders is naturally sorted and added to a shard. This strategy allows you to schedule updates in a time zone based on the local load and demand pattern if users of the same region are in the same shard. However, ideal balancing between shards is not provided by the range strategy.

This strategy is aimed to reduce the chance of hotspots (shards that receive a disproportionate amount of load). It distributes the data across the shards so that a balance between each shard&rsquo;s size and the average load that each shard will encounter is achieved. The shard is computed to store an item based on a hash of one or more data attributes. The chosen hashing function distributes data evenly among the shards. The diagram illustrates sharding tenant data based on a hash of tenant IDs.

This strategy provides an opportunity to have more even data and load distribution. Applying hash functions allows you to complete the request routing directly. A map shouldn&rsquo;t be maintained. Keep in mind that computing the hash may impose an additional overhead.

Sharding Tips

Now, when you became familiar with the main Sharding strategies, let&rsquo;s have a special look at the list of tips that can be helpful when applying the Sharding patterns. They include shard balancing, key uniqueness, reference data replication, referential integrity, and others.

Click on the hot spots to receive the tips.

Complementing Other Partitioning Forms. Vertical and functional forms of partitioning can be complemented by sharding. For example, a single shard may include entities partitioned vertically, and a functional partition can be implemented as multiple shards.

Shard Balancing. Shards should be kept balanced to process a similar volume of I/O. It is required to rebalance the shards at regular intervals in order to ensure even distribution and diminish the chance of hotspots as data is inserted and deleted. Rebalancing operations can increase costs.

Stable Data for Shards Keys. Changes in shard keys can result in moving the correspondent data item between shards, increasing the amount of work executed by update operations.

Key Uniqueness. Shard keys must be unique.

Query Effectiveness/Complexity. Try not to implement a sharding system that leads to applications dealing with a large number of queries joining data stored in different shards. Accessing a single shard is more effective than retrieving data from multiple shards.

Reference Data Replication. Consider replicating reference data to all shards. If an operation retrieving data from a shard also references static or slow-moving data as a part of the same query, add this data to the shard.

Referential Integrity and Consistency. Minimize operations that impact data in multiple shards as it can be hard to maintain referential integrity and consistency between shards.

The Sharding pattern provides multiple benefits. You can add further shards running on additional storage nodes to scale the system. This way, the system can use off-the-shelf hardware instead of specialized and expensive computers for each storage node. You can reduce contention and improve performance by balancing the workload across shards. In the cloud, shards can be located physically close to the users that will access the data. Note that the Sharding pattern should be used when a data store will likely need to scale beyond the resources available to a single storage node or improve performance by reducing contention in a data store.

Lesson Summary

In this lesson, you received detailed information about three primary performance and scalability patterns, learned their key characteristics, what can be achieved by applying them, and cases when using each of these patterns is recommended. You learned how these patterns work, paid attention to some examples and tips so that you can define which one fits your project best.

L7: Architectural Patterns. Integration Patterns

Bookmark

Lesson Introduction

This lesson provides an introduction to the integration pattern as well as gives more detailed information about messaging systems and their components. Understanding of the integration styles, message concepts, and system management patterns can help guide solution architects toward employing practices that translate across any integration project regardless of the industry.

Integration Patterns

Integration aims to make component agnostic and usable quickly across the business, so it can be accessed and handled by its constituents. And in order to make that data usable even more quickly, integration patterns can be created to standardize the integration process.

There are commonly used patterns in the integration category&mdash;the File Transfer, Shared database, Remote Procedure Invocation, and Messaging. The majority of the Messaging patterns are summarized below. The upcoming sections look at some of them in more detail.

Click on the hot spots to learn more about them.

Messaging patterns: Message; Command Message; Document Message; Event Message; Request-Reply; Return Address; Correlation Identifier; Message Sequence; Message Expiration; Format Indicator.

Message Routing: Pipes-and-Filters; Message Router; Content-based Router; Message Filter; Dynamic Router; Recipient List; Splitter; Aggregator; Resequencer; Composed Msg. Processor; Scatter-Gather; Routing Slip; Process Manager; Message Broker.

Message Transformation: Message Translator; Envelope Wrapper; Content Enricher; Content Filter; Claim Check; Normalizer; Canonical Data Model.

Messaging Endpoints: Message Endpoint; Messaging Gateway; Messaging Mapper; Transactional Client; Polling Consumer; Event-driven Consumer; Competing; Consumers; Message Dispatcher; Selective Consumer; Durable Subscriber; Idempotent Receiver; Service Activator.

Messaging Channels: Message Channel; Point-to-Point Channel; Publish-Subscr. Channel; Datatype Channel; Invalid Message Channel; Dead Letter Channel; Guaranteed Delivery; Channel Adapter; Messaging Bridge; Message Bus.

Systems Mgmt: Control Bus; Detour; Wire Tap; Message History; Message Store; Smart Proxy; Test Message; Channel Purger.

Messaging As a Way of Applications' Integration

This lesson explains how to use messaging to integrate applications. Messaging is a technology that enables high-speed, asynchronous, program-to-program communication with reliable delivery. Programs communicate by sending packets of data called messages to each other.

Click on the flip cards to learn about messaging process components.

Channels

Channels, also known as queues, are logical pathways that connect the programs and convey messages. A channel behaves like a collection or array of messages, but one that is magically shared across multiple computers and can be used concurrently by multiple applications.

Sender

A sender or producer is a program that sends a message by writing a message to a channel.

Receiver

A receiver or consumer is a program that receives a message by reading (and deleting) it from a channel.

Messaging capabilities are typically provided by a separate software system called a messaging system or message-oriented middleware, which manages messaging in the way a database system manages data persistence.

If you are wondering why you should use messaging, there are some reasons. Messaging is more immediate than File Transfer, better encapsulated than Shared Database, and more reliable than Remote Procedure Invocation. However, that's just the beginning of the advantages that can be gained using messaging.

Messaging Gateway

How to encapsulate access to the messaging system from the rest of the application? Use a Messaging Gateway, a class that wraps messaging-specific method calls and exposes domain-specific methods to the application. The Messaging Gateway encapsulates messaging-specific code (e.g., the code required to send or receive a message) and separates it from the rest of the application code. This way, only the Messaging Gateway code knows about the messaging system; the rest of the application code does not.

The Messaging Gateway provides a business function to the rest of the application in a way that it doesn't require the application to set such properties as Message.MessageReadPropertyFilter.AppSpecific. It is a gateway that exposes methods like GetCreditScore that allows you to accept strictly typed parameters as any other method. A Messaging Gateway is considered as a messaging-specific version of the more common Gateway pattern.

Many Messaging Gateways send a message to another component and expect a reply. Such a Messaging Gateway can be implemented in two different ways: Blocking (Synchronous) Messaging Gateway and Event-Driven (Asynchronous) Messaging Gateway. Now, let's figure out some reasons to use this pattern.

Click on the tabs to learn more about why to use Messaging Gateway.

The Messaging Gateway makes it easier for the application to maintain state if it allows the application to pass a reference to an arbitrary set of data to the request method. The Messaging Gateway will then pass this data back to the application with the callback. This way, the application has all the necessary data available when the asynchronous callback is invoked. This type of interaction is called ACT (Asynchronous Completion Token).

Messaging Gateways make great testing vehicles. Because all the nasty messaging code is wrapped behind a narrow, domain-specific interface, you can easily create an implementation of this interface. Simply separate interface and implementation and provide two implementations: one "real" implementation that accesses the messaging infrastructure and a "fake" implementation for testing purposes.

Request-Reply

When an application sends a message, how can it get a response from the receiver? Send a pair of Request-Reply messages, each on its own channel. When two applications communicate via Messaging, the communication is one-way. In some cases, applications may want a two-way conversation.

The Request-Reply integration pattern facilitates two-way communication by ensuring that a sender gets a response or reply from the receiver after sending a request message. This pattern sends a pair of Request-Reply messages, each on its own channel. Request-Reply has two participants.

Click on the hot spots to learn more about these participants.

Requestor. Sends a request message and waits for a reply message.

Replier. Receives the request message and responds with a reply message.

Request Channel. The request channel can be a Point-to-Point Channel or a Publish-Subscribe Channel. The difference is whether the request should be broadcast to all interested parties or should only be processed by a single consumer.

Reply Channel. The reply channel is almost always point-to-point because it usually makes no sense to broadcast replies&ndash;they should only be returned to the requestor.

An example of using Request-Reply is SOAP messages. SOAP messages come in Request-Reply pairs. A SOAP request message indicates a service the sender wishes to invoke on the receiver, whereas a SOAP response message contains the result of the service invocation. The response message either contains a result value or a fault&mdash;the SOAP equivalent of an exception.

You can also find some additional examples for using Request-Reply here.

Guaranteed Delivery

How can the sender make sure that a message will be delivered, even if the messaging system fails? Use Guaranteed Delivery to make messages persistent so that they are not lost even if the messaging system crashes.

Click on the video to explore more about Guaranteed Delivery. Alternatively, you may click&nbsp;here to download a text script to find out what you will learn.

Now, let's figure out when it is better to use or avoid this pattern. Persistence increases reliability but at the expense of performance. Thus, if it's OK to lose messages when the messaging system crashes or is shut down, avoid using Guaranteed Delivery so that messages will move through the messaging system faster. Let's overview the scenarios when you should consider using Guaranteed Delivery.

Click on the dots to learn more about Guaranteed Delivery use-cases.

High-traffic Scenarios

Guaranteed Delivery can consume a large amount of disk space in high-traffic scenarios. If a producer generates hundreds or thousands of messages per second, then a network outage that lasts multiple hours could use up a huge amount of disk space. Because the network is unavailable, the messages have to be stored on the producing computer's local disk drive, which may not be designed to hold this much data. For these reasons, some messaging systems allow you to configure a retry timeout parameter that specifies how long messages are buffered inside the messaging system. In some high-traffic applications (e.g., streaming stock quotes to terminals), this timeout may have to be set to a short time span, for example, a few minutes.

Testing and Debugging

It can also be useful to turn off Guaranteed Delivery during testing and debugging. This makes it easy to purge all message channels by stopping and restarting the messaging server. Messages that are still queued up can make it very tedious to debug even simple messaging programs. For example, you may have a sender and a receiver connected by a Point-to-Point Channel. If a message is still stored on the channel, the receiver will process that message before any new message that the sender produces. This is a common debugging pitfall in asynchronous, guaranteed messaging. Many commercial messaging implementations also allow you to purge queues individually to allow a fresh restart during testing.

Now, let's figure out how this pattern can be applied in real-life examples. The first example describes the use of Guaranteed Delivery in a stock trading system; the second refers to the IBM WebSphere MQ, which is a family of message-oriented middleware products.

Click on the dropdowns to explore examples.

In a stock trading system, trade requests and trade confirmations should probably be sent with Guaranteed Delivery to help ensure that none are lost. Likewise, change-of-address announcements should probably be sent with Guaranteed Delivery. On the other hand, price updates probably do not require Guaranteed Delivery; losing some of them is not significant, and their frequency makes the overhead of Guaranteed Delivery prohibitive.

The stock trading example says that some price-change subscribers may wish to be durable. If so, then perhaps the price-change channel should guarantee delivery as well. Yet other subscribers may not need to be durable nor want to suffer the overhead of Guaranteed Delivery. How can these different needs be met? The system may wish to implement two price-change channels, one with Guaranteed Delivery and another without. Only subscribers that require all updates should subscribe to the persistent channel, and their subscriptions should be durable. The publisher may wish to publish updates less frequently on the persistent channel because of its increased overhead.

In WebSphere MQ, Guaranteed Delivery can be set on a per-channel basis or a per-message basis. If the channel is not persistent, the messages cannot be persistent. If the channel is persistent, the channel can be configured such that all messages sent on that channel are automatically persistent or such that an individual message can be sent persistently or non-persistently.

Aggregator

How to combine the results of individual but related messages so that they can be processed as a whole? Use a stateful filter, an aggregator, to collect and store individual messages until a complete set of related messages has been received. Then, the aggregator publishes a single message distilled from the individual messages.

The aggregator is a special filter that receives a stream of messages and identifies messages that are correlated. Once a complete set of messages has been received, the aggregator collects information from each correlated message and publishes a single, aggregated message to the output channel for further processing.

There are a number of strategies for aggregator completeness conditions. The available strategies primarily depend on whether you know how many messages to expect or not. The aggregator could know the number of sub-messages to expect because it received a copy of the original composite message or because each individual message contains the total count. So, let's consider aggregation strategies.

Scroll to learn more about these strategies.

"Wait for All"

Wait until all responses are received. An incomplete order may not be meaningful. So, if not all items are received within a certain timeout period, an error condition should be raised by the aggregator. This approach may give you the best basis for decision-making but may also be the slowest and most brittle (and you need to know how many messages to expect).

"Time Out"

Wait for a specified length of time for responses and then make a decision by evaluating those responses received within that time limit. If no responses are received, the system may report an exception or retry. This is useful if incoming responses are scored, and only the message with the highest score is used. This approach is common in "bidding" scenarios.

"First Best"


Wait only until the first (fastest) response is received and ignore all other responses. You should keep in mind that this approach is the fastest but ignores a lot of information. However, note that it may be practical in a bidding or quoting scenario where response time is critical.

"Time Out with Override"

Wait for a specified amount of time or until a message with a preset minimum score has been received. In this scenario, you are willing to abort early if you find a very favorable response; otherwise, you keep on going until time is up. If no clear winner was found at that point, rank-ordering among all the messages received so far occurs.

"External Event"

Sometimes the aggregation is concluded by the arrival of an external business event. E.g., in the financial industry, the end of the trading day may signal the end of an aggregation of incoming price quotes. The aggregator can listen for the Event Message on a special control channel or receive a specially formatted message that indicates the end of the aggregation.

Select the "Best" Answer

This approach assumes that there is a single best answer, e.g., the lowest bid for an identical item. The aggregator can make the decision and only pass the "best" message on. In real life, selection criteria are rarely this simple. E.g., the "best" bid for an item may depend on the time of delivery, the number of available items, whether the vendor is on the preferred vendor list, etc.

Condense Data

An Aggregator can be used to reduce message traffic from a high-traffic source. In these cases, it may make sense to compute an average of individual messages or add numeric fields from each message into a single message. This works best if each message represents a numeric value, for example, the number of orders received.

Collect Data for Later Evaluation

It is not always possible for an aggregator to make the decision of how to select the best answer. In those cases, it makes sense to use an Aggregator to collect the individual messages and combine them into a single message. This message may simply be a compilation of the individual's message data. The aggregation decision may be made later by a separate component.

In many instances, the aggregation strategy is driven by parameters. For example, a strategy that waits for a specified amount of time can be configured with the maximum wait time.

Now, let's explore how aggregators can be useful in different aggregations. Let's consider a Loan broker as an example. An Aggregator can be used to select the best loan quote from the loan quote messages returned by the banks. The loan broker example uses an initialized Aggregator&mdash;the Recipient List informs the aggregator of the number of quote messages to expect.

Guaranteed Delivery and Aggregator Example

Let's figure out how an Aggregator can be used as Missing Message Detector. The system sends a message through a sequence of components, which are unfortunately quite unreliable. Even using Guaranteed Delivery will not correct this problem because, typically, the systems themselves fail after they consumed a message. Because the applications are not Transactional Clients, the message-in-progress is lost. Now, let's pay attention to the scheme below.


To help remedy this situation, an incoming is routed through two parallel paths: once through the required but unreliable components and once around the components using Guaranteed Delivery. An Aggregator recombines the messages from the two paths. Now, let's examine this example more specifically.

Click on the step-by-step interactivity to explore the process shown in the scheme above.

The aggregator uses a "Time Out with Override" completeness condition, which means that the aggregator completes if either the timeout is reached or the two associated messages have been received.

The aggregation algorithm depends on which condition is fulfilled first. If two messages are received, the processed message is passed on without modification. If the timeout event occurs, you know that one of the components failed and "ate" the message.

As a result, you instruct the aggregator to publish an error message that alerts the operators that one of the components has failed. Unfortunately, the components have to be restarted manually, but a more sophisticated configuration could likely restart the component and re-send any lost messages. Unfortunately, the components have to be restarted manually, but a more sophisticated configuration could likely restart the component and re-send any lost messages.

Content Enricher

How to communicate with another system if the message originator does not have all the required data items available? Use a specialized transformer, a content enricher, to access an external data source in order to augment a message with missing information.

You should be aware that when sending messages from one system to another, it is common for the target system to require more information than the source system can provide.

Click on the dots to learn more about content enricher.

For example, incoming address messages may just contain the ZIP code because the designers felt that storing a redundant state code would be superfluous, or an order message sent by the order management system may just contain an order number, but you need to find the customer ID associated with that order, so you can pass it to the customer management system.

The Content Enricher uses information inside the incoming message (e.g., key fields) to retrieve data from an external source. After the Content Enricher retrieves the required data from the resource, it appends the data to the message. The original information from the incoming message may be carried over into the resulting message or may no longer be needed, depending on the specific needs of the receiving application.

Content Enricher Examples

Let's consider the following example. A hospital scheduling system publishes a message announcing that the patient has completed a doctor's visit. The message contains the patient's first name, his or her patient ID, and the date of the visit. In order for the accounting system to log this visit and inform the insurance company, it requires the full patient name, the insurance carrier, and the patient's social security number. However, the scheduling system does not store this information; it is contained in the customer care system. There are three options, as described below.

Click on the tabs to overview these options.

The scheduling system can be modified so it can store additional information. When the customer's information changes in the customer care system, the changes need to be replicated to the scheduling system. The scheduling system can now send a message that includes all required information. Unfortunately, this approach requires a modification to the scheduling system's internal structure. In most cases, the scheduling system is a packaged application and may not allow this type of modification. Also, even if the scheduling system is customizable, you need to consider that you are making a change to the system based on the specific needs of another system. For example, if you also want to send a letter to the patient confirming the visit, you have to change the scheduling system again to accommodate the customer's mailing address.

The scheduling system could request the SSN and carrier data from the customer care system just before it is sending the "Doctor Visit" message. This solves the first problem&mdash;you no longer have to modify the storage of the scheduling system. However, the scheduling system needs to know that the SSN and carrier information is required in order to notify the accounting system. Therefore, the semantics of the message is more similar to "Notify Insurance" than "Doctor Visit". In a loosely coupled system, you rather send an event message and let the other systems decide what to do. In addition, this solution couples the scheduling system more tightly to the customer care system. This ties the scheduling system to both the accounting system and the customer care system. This type of coupling is undesirable because it leads to brittle integration solutions.

The message can be sent to the customer care system first instead of the accounting system. The customer care system can then fetch all the required information and send a message with all the required data to the accounting system. This decouples the scheduling system nicely from the subsequent flow of the message. However, now you implement the business rule that the insurance company receives a bill after the patient visits the doctor inside the customer care system. This requires modifying the logic inside the customer care system. If the customer care system is a packaged application, this modification may be impossible. Even if it is implemented, the customer care system is now indirectly responsible for sending bill messages. If some of the fields have to be retrieved from other systems, it is the same situation as in the beginning.

Loading drag and drop problem.

Now, let's figure out how to apply a Content Enricher to this use-case. You can insert the Content Enricher to retrieve the additional data from the customer care system, as shown in the scheme below.

This way, the scheduling system is nicely decoupled from having to deal with insurance information or the customer care system. All it has to do is publish the "Doctor Visit" message. The Content Enricher component takes care of retrieving the required data. The accounting system also remains independent of the customer care system.

If you want to receive some more examples, let's have a look at one additional use-case for the Content Enricher.

Click on the dropdown to discover additional use-case.

A Content Enricher is also commonly used when communicating with external parties that require messages to be compliant with a specific message standard. Most of these standards require large messages with a long list of data. You can usually simplify your internal operations significantly if you keep internal messages as simple as possible and then use the Content Enricher to add the missing fields whenever you send a message outside of the organization. Likewise, you can use a Content Filter to strip unnecessary information from incoming messages (see the scheme below).

Message History

How can you effectively analyze and debug the flow of messages in a loosely coupled system? You should attach a Message History, which contains a list of all applications that the message passed through after it was originated, to the message.

The advantage of the message-based systems is the loose coupling between users, which allows the message sender and recipient to make no prediction about the identity of each other. When retrieving a message from a message channel, a message recipient neither know nor care which application sent the message to the channel. The message doesn't refer to any specific sender, and according to the definition, it is considered as self-contained. This fact is known as an architectural strength of message-based systems.

Move the pieces of the diagram below in order to rebuild the scheme. Click on the piece you want to move, and then on the piece you want to be replaced with the first one.

However, one and the same property may complicate the process of debugging and analyzing dependencies. Is it possible to analyze the effect of a change in the message format if you are not sure where a message goes, and, moreover, is it hard to fix a problem with the message if you don't know which application issued a message? The list of all components that the message passed through is included in the Message History. The originator and each component that handles the message adds one entry to the list. The Message History should be included in the message header as it comprises system-specific control information. If you keep this information in the header, the message body, which contains application-specific data, will be separated from it. Now, let's pay attention to the example.

Many EAI integration suites include support for a Message History. For example, the message header of every ActiveEnterprise message includes a tracking field that maintains a list of all components through which the message has passed. In this context, it is important to note that a TIBCO ActiveEnterprise component assigns outgoing messages the same message ID as the consumed message. This makes tracking of messages through multiple components easier, but it also means that the message ID is not a system-wide unique property because multiple individual messages share the same ID.

If you know to read more about integration patterns, pay attention to this book.

This lesson was focused on the application integration patterns. You have learned about several of the most common ones and the way of their implementation into each step of the message communication pipeline. The general understanding of integration styles and system management patterns helps solution architects use integration practices regardless of the industry the project is related to.

Topic: Architectural Styles and Patterns / Architectural Patterns: Integration Patterns

L8: Architectural Patterns. Fault Tolerance Patterns

Bookmark

Lesson Introduction

This lesson will cover the fault tolerance patterns in microservices. You will learn the definition of fault tolerance and get acquainted with an important redundancy concept, its types, and methods. You will also become familiar with the algorithms that can be applied to prevent errors and manage system failures if they occur. You will learn how the isolation patterns help not to let faults in one part of a solution to take the entire system down.

Fault Tolerance Definition

Let&rsquo;s start with a definition of &ldquo;Fault Tolerance&rdquo;. According to Wikipedia, &ldquo;Fault tolerance is the property that enables a system to continue operating properly in the event of the failure of some (one or more faults within) of its components. A fault-tolerant design enables a system to continue its intended operation, possibly at a reduced level, rather than failing completed, when some part of the system fails.&rdquo;

Error Life Cycle

Several things can be done during the design of the software process to support fault-tolerant operation and a variety of fault-tolerant patterns that cover all the stages of the error lifecycle. The following sections describe just some of them.

Redundancy Overview

Software poses some particular challenges and also provides new opportunities to exploit redundancy. For example, while simple replication of components can handle some classes of production faults typical of hardware design, it cannot deal with many failures that derive from the development and integration problems that often occur in software systems. On the other hand, software systems are amenable to various redundancy forms not found in hardware systems.

Redundancy is the duplication of critical components or functions of a system aimed to increase its reliability.

Click on the step-by-step interactivity to overview the process of using redundancy.

Context/Risk

In case of errors, the system, which is composed of many software and hardware components, can be unavailable.

Intention

Reduce the amount of time between error detection and the resumption of normal operation after error recovery.

Solution

  • Introduce redundancy in your system
  • Redundancy can be spatial, temporal, and informational
    • Spatial redundancy can be Active-Active, Active-Passive, N+1
      • In Active-Passive mode, the standby can be hot, warm, or cold

Redundant components can be either triggered preventively to avoid failures, or exploited reactively in response to failures. In the second case, the system must at a minimum detect a failure, and therefore decide how to exploit the redundancy of the system to cope with the failure. The component of the system that makes these decisions is called the adjudicator.

From the Software Architecture viewpoint, redundancy can be introduced either at the intra- or inter-component level. When introduced at the intra-component level, redundancy does not alter the structure of the connections between components, but only the single components. This is the case for example of wrappers that filter component interactions, robust data structures that introduce redundancy at the data structure level to handle data related faults, and automatic workarounds that exploit redundancy that is implicitly present in the program. When introduced at the inter-component level, you can recognize a few recurrent patterns.

Click on the hot spots to overview these patterns.

Parallel evaluation. In the parallel evaluation pattern, an adjudicator evaluates the results of several alternative implementations that are executed in parallel. The adjudicator is often a simple voting mechanism that identifies failures. This is the case for example of N-version programming that runs N different versions with the same input configuration.

Parallel selection. In the parallel selection pattern, the adjudicator is active at the end of each program executed in parallel to validate the result and disable failing components. The pattern is implemented in self-checking programming.

Sequential Alternative. In the sequential alternative pattern, alternative programs are activated when adjudicators detect failures. This pattern is implemented by recovery blocks.

As was already mentioned, there are several types of redundancy. They refer to spatial, temporal, and informational redundancy. Now, let&rsquo;s overview these types more specifically and learn about each of them.

Click on the video to learn more about redundancy types. Alternatively, you may click here to download a text script to find out what you will learn.

If you want to know more about redundancy, examine this resource.

Spatial Redundancy Methods

After getting acquainted with key types of redundancy, let&rsquo;s move to the methods applicable to spatial redundancy. Let&rsquo;s explore the three most common techniques, which include Active-Active, Active-Passive, and N+M redundancy.

Click on the dropdowns to learn more about spatial redundancy methods.

Active-Active method provides totally redundant units of mitigation for critical functionality. At any given time, both of the elements are active and load sharing. However, either of the elements is capable of processing the entire load. Active-Active contributes the fastest recovery, but it also has a high cost because there is much more capability in the system than needed for an ordinary workload. Active-Active implies a pairing between the two active units.

When in an Active-Passive situation, the standby element is again paired with the active one. It does not perform useful work, meaning that the same resources are required as in the Active-Active situation, but the standby is idle during the normal operation. If you have chosen a redundancy regime, it might greatly affect the speed of switching. When redundant elements are &ldquo;hot&rdquo; standbys, the switchover can be very fast with minimum outage of the main application. If the standby element is &ldquo;warm&rdquo;, it will need time to to the same application state. Checkpoints will assist in getting there faster. When the standby is considered &ldquo;cold&rdquo;, it should be started from an inactive state, which requires additional time. You can treat it as a warm standby once it starts.

In situations where a one-to-one relationship, such as described by the previous two methods, is too expensive, N+M Redundancy is a useful technique. In this configuration, there are N active elements processing the workload of the system. There are also M redundant standby elements in the system, ready to assume control when a failure occurs in any of the N.

Heartbeat Pattern

Heartbeat is a fault detection mechanism that employs a periodic message exchange between a system monitor and the process being monitored. A special case of heartbeat is when the process being monitored periodically resets the watchdog timer in its monitor to prevent it from expiring and thus signaling a fault. For systems where scalability is a concern, transport and processing overhead can be reduced by piggybacking heartbeat messages onto other control messages exchanged between the process monitored and the distributed system controller. The big difference between heartbeat and ping/echo is who holds the responsibility for initiating a health check: the monitor or the component itself.

Click on the flip cards to learn more about the heartbeat pattern.

Context/Risk

Modules- or services-based architecture where each component can be unavailable eventually.

&rsaquo;

Intention

Errors must be detected as quickly as possible to minimize the mean time to repair the attribute of availability.

&rsaquo;

Solution

  • The health reports, or heartbeats, should occur at regular intervals
  • During busy periods the realistic threshold is very important to reduce the unnecessary overhead that is draining processing and messaging bandwidth from real work
  • Can be from the monitor to monitored task, or vice versa

Leaky Bucket Counter

The leaky bucket is an algorithm based on how a bucket with a leak will overflow if either the average rate at which water is poured in exceeds the rate at which the bucket leaks or if more water than the capacity of the bucket is poured in all at once and how the water leaks from the bucket at an (almost) constant rate.

The gif shows the general principles of a leaky bucket counter. Error reports fill the bucket, while an allowable number of errors is deducted from the bucket constantly as it leaks. If the rate at which the bucket fills is larger than the leaking rate, an error is triggered.

Let&rsquo;s figure out how this algorithm can be applied for error preventions and managing system failures.

Click on the step-by-step interactivity to overview the process of leaky bucket counter defining.

Context/Risk

Your system is intended to recognize and correct errors automatically. Not all errors are so critical that their first occurrence stimulates error processing.

Intention

You need to know if an error is transient or intermittent.

Solution

You need to define your leaky bucket counter

  • Initial value at system start-up
  • Incrementing when a specified issue occurs
  • Decrementing over a specified period (but never less than initial value)
  • If exceeding a predetermined upper threshold, handle the error as permanent

A leaky bucket counter can be used (but is not limited to these use-cases) in traffic shaping or traffic policing. Now, let&rsquo;s pay attention to some real examples and use-cases which require the leaky bucket counter implementation.

Click on the tabs to overview examples for using leaky bucket counter.

The example from 1A/1B processor systems in AT&amp;T telecommunication products is as follows: As memory words (dynamic RAM) got weak, the memory module would generate a parity error trap. Examples include both 1A processor dynamic RAM and 1B processor static RAM. The counter is decremented for each fault and incremented periodically. There are different initial values and leak rates for different subsystems: e.g., it is a half-hour for the 1A memory subsystem. The 1A dynamic RAM strategy specifies that the first failure in a store causes the store to be taken out of service, diagnosed, and then automatically restored to service. On the second, third, and fourth failure you just leave it in service. For the fifth episode within the timing window, take the unit out of service, diagnose it, and leave it out.

A leaky bucket counter is used in the network device with traffic shaping functions. A network device with bandwidth usage control functions uses a leaky bucket algorithm to provide a traffic service conforming to given user parameters. A leaky bucket counter produces a new leaky-bucket (LB) count at predetermined cell slot intervals by adding an output rate parameter to the previous count and then by subtracting therefrom a full rate parameter if a cell output request signal is active. An upper limit calculator determines an upper limit for such a limit, thereby producing a modified LB count. When the modified LB count from the count modifier equals or exceeds an output reference value, a comparator activates an output timing signal, allowing transmission of a pending cell in a buffer.

Voting

Voting was briefly introduced in the Quality Attributes submodule, Lesson Reliability. However, in order to build a more comprehensive view, let&rsquo;s observe how this pattern works more deeply. This pattern prevents a single component&rsquo;s failure from causing a failure of a complete system.

Click on the hot spots to learn more about the voting pattern.

Components. The components are replicated to perform the same operation in parallel.

Voter. The N produced results are compared by a majority-voting system (a voter) in order to determine the correct result. The system functions correctly as long as the majority of components are fault-free.

The outputs of N components are processed by a majority voter that can mask (N &ndash; 1)/2 faults.

In order to make majority voting possible, N is selected to be odd. In the basic case, N is selected to three, then a fault of one component can be masked. Now, let&rsquo;s figure out some additional aspects of this pattern applying.

Click on the flip cards to see the main aspects.

Context/Risk

There is a case when redundancy provides multiple answers, and a need to decide what answer should be used.

&rsaquo;

Intention

Arbitrate the results from the redundant components.

&rsaquo;

Solution

  • Devise a voting strategy:
    • Majority vote (uneven node number)
    • Generalized median voting &ndash; select a result that is the median by removing extremes
    • Formalized plurality voting &ndash; divide results into partitions, choose random from the largest partition
  • In case of any disagreement, treat the element that loses the vote as erroneous
  • Make sure you can trust the entity taking the vote (triple-mode redundancy)

Isolation Patterns

The general goal of any isolation pattern is to avoid faults in one part of a solution to take the entire system down. Splitting the system into parts that are isolated from each other helps to avoid cascade failures. The most well-known patterns of this type are bulkheads, which connect elements into a &ldquo;unit of failure&rdquo; and loose coupling characterized by asynchronous communication and complete isolation.

A ship is split into multiple small compartments using bulkheads. Bulkheads are used to seal parts of the ship to prevent the entire ship from sinking in case of a flood. Similarly, failures should be expected when you&rsquo;re designing software. Let&rsquo;s consider the bulkhead pattern by focusing on the example.

In the example below, the bulkhead pattern is applied to a database cache. In the non-partitioned database cache, the failure of the cache spreads to the services interacting directly with the database, leading to an application failure. But in the partitioned example, the partition for service C has failed independently, resulting in the failure of service C without immediately causing failure in the other two services.

Swipe the illustration to the&nbsp;right to see the non-partitioned database cache and to the&nbsp;left to see the way of bulkhead pattern applying.

While useful for preventing catastrophic failures, the bulkhead pattern does add complexity to your application. You should be careful when applying this pattern and other ones in the isolation group. Let&rsquo;s figure out when isolation patterns should be used and when they should be avoided.

Click on the flip cards to learn more about good and bad isolation pattern use-cases.


Use Isolation Pattern

  • To isolate resources used to consume a set of backend services, especially if the application can provide some level of functionality even when one of the services is not responding.
  • To isolate critical consumers from standard consumers.
  • To protect the application from cascading failures.


Avoid isolation Pattern

  • This pattern may not be suitable when less efficient use of resources may not be acceptable in the project.
  • It is also not suitable when the added complexity is unnecessary.

Circuit Breaker

This pattern describes how to safely connect different parts of the system so that failures do not spread uncontrollably across them. Its origin lies in electrical engineering: in order to protect electrical circuits from each other and introduce decoupled failure domains, a technique was established of breaking the connection when the transmitted power exceeds a given threshold. Let&rsquo;s discover what problems this pattern is aimed to solve by viewing an example.

Click on the dots to overview the example.

Assume you are making a service request to buy 100 shares of Microsoft. As the service consumer, the last thing you want to do is time out the request just when the service has successfully placed the trade and is about to give you your order confirmation number. You can try to resubmit the trade, but you have to add complexity into your service to determine if this is a new trade or a duplicate. Since you don&rsquo;t have a confirmation number from the first trade, it&rsquo;s going to be challenging to see whether the trade was successful or not.

Usually, a timeout value is peak load performance time multiplied by two: i.e., if a service gives a response in two seconds and three seconds in normal and peak load, respectively, then the time out value should be six seconds. On the surface, this idea seems good. However, later on, while creating a waiting time period of six seconds for each request call to determine whether the service is available does not sound like a good idea. Usually, the end-users click the &ldquo;Submit&rdquo; button within two to three seconds of no response.

To solve this anti-pattern, you can use a circuit breaker design pattern, which can improve the stability and resiliency of an application. The general concept of the circuit breaker is pretty simple. A protected function call is wrapped in a circuit breaker object that checks the failures. If the failure achieved a particular threshold, the circuit breaker trips, and all further calls to the circuit breaker return with an error, and no protected call has been made at all. Typically, a monitor alert is needed if a circuit breaker trips.

A simple circuit breaker can avoid making a protected call when the circuit is open but needs an external intervention to reset it when things are well again. For electrical circuit breakers used in buildings, it is a reasonable approach, but with software circuit breakers, you can have the breaker itself detect if the underlying calls are working again. You can implement this self-resetting behavior by trying the protected call again after a suitable interval and resetting the breaker should it succeed.

Move the pieces of the diagram below in order to rebuild the scheme. Click on the piece you want to move, and then on the piece you want to be replaced with the first one.

As you saw in the scheme above, circuit breaker pattern can be implemented as a stateful software component that switches between three states: closed (requests can flow freely), open (requests are rejected without being submitted to the remote resource), and half-open (one probe request is allowed to decide whether to close the circuit again). Now, let&rsquo;s consider one more example.

If you want to know more about these states, click here.

Click on the dropdown to view an example.

First, imagine a payment service as a part of a shopping platform. When a client wants to make a payment, the payment service should ensure there&rsquo;s no fraudulent intention. To do that, it asks for a fraud check service.

The request from the payment service to the fraud check service is passed through the circuit breaker. After two internal server errors, the circuit opens, and subsequent requests are blocked. After some waiting time, the circuit goes to the half-open state. In this state, it will allow one request to pass and change back to the open state in case it fails or to the closed one in case of success. The next request succeeds, so the circuit is closed again.

If you want to know more, follow this link.

Same as with the other patterns, there are some good use-cases for the circuit breaker pattern. However, in some situations, its usage should be avoided. Let&rsquo;s have a more detailed look at the situations when you should or should not use this pattern.

Click on the flip cards to learn when to use or avoid using a circuit breaker.

Use this pattern

  • To prevent an application from trying to invoke a remote service or access a shared resource if this operation is highly likely to fail.

This pattern isn&rsquo;t recommended

  • For handling access to local private resources in an application, such as in-memory data structure. In this environment, using a circuit breaker would add overhead to your system.
  • As a substitute for handling exceptions in the business logic of your applications.

Lesson Summary

In this lesson, you have learned about the importance of fault tolerance for any architecture and gained an understanding of which patterns are aimed to prevent the collapse of the entire system. You&rsquo;ve looked through a detailed overview of the redundancy concept and its types. After completing this lesson, you are prepared to apply this theoretical knowledge to the real cases and to design solutions that can continue intended operations even when some parts of them fail.
