L9: Architectural Patterns. Security Patterns

Bookmark

Lesson Introduction

This lesson is focused on architectural security patterns, which aim to provide extra layers of security to the application. You will learn the three most common ones and their pros and cons. After completing this lesson, you will be able to determine the pattern that suits your system the best.

Federated Identity Pattern

Federated identity security pattern provides a solution to several issues and risks for the system. It is used to delegate authentication responsibility to an external identity provider.

Click on the video to learn more about this pattern. Alternatively, you may click here to download a text script to find out what you will learn.

Federated identity security is useful when your application needs to provide the Single Sign-On (SSO) experience to the users. It can also be used when the applications need to authenticate users with multiple partners; in Software as a Service (SaaS) applications where tenants of the SaaS application can authenticate using a suitable identity provider, etc. Let&rsquo;s take a closer look at the way it works.

Click on the step-by-step interactivity to discover what problems this pattern aims to solve and how this can be conducted.

Context/Risk

The basic requirement from the users&rsquo; side is working with multiple applications that are hosted by the organizations they&rsquo;re dealing with. Disadvantages of using different credentials for multiple applications are:

  • Disjoint user experience. When users have different credentials for different applications, they can forget which credentials correspond to each application.
  • Security vulnerabilities. If a user leaves a company, his account should be deprovisioned at once. It can be overlooked in large organizations.
  • Complicated user management. Administrators should manage users&rsquo; credentials and provide password reminders.

Intention

  • Eliminate disjointed user experience
  • Minimize security vulnerabilities
  • Simplify user management

Solution

Separate user authentication from the application code and delegate authentication to a trusted identity provider.

Federated Identity: Diagram

The challenges and solutions described in the previous section can be illustrated by a diagram below, which contains the main components of the process and the interrelations between them. The figure illustrates federated identity pattern when a client application needs to access a service that requires authentication. The authentication is performed by an IdP that works in concert with an STS. The IdP issues security tokens that provide information about the authenticated user. This information, referred to as claims, includes the user&rsquo;s identity and might also include other personal information such as role membership and more granular access rights. For better understanding, let&rsquo;s inspect the diagram below.

Move the pieces of the diagram below in order to rebuild the scheme. Click on the piece you want to move, and then on the piece you want to be replaced with the first one.

Federated Identity Use-Cases

Federal identity pattern is used to solve multiple scenarios for user access and identification, both inside and outside the system. Such scenarios are single sign-on in the enterprise, federated identity with multiple partners, and federated identity in SaaS applications. Let&rsquo;s learn more about how this pattern is applicable in the selected scenarios.

Click on the tabs to learn more about the good use cases for federal identity pattern.

In this scenario, you have to authenticate employees for corporate cloud-based applications outside the corporate security boundary. Users are not required to sign in every time they visit an application. User experience is similar to using on-premises applications. Once the user is authenticated, he has access to all relevant applications without signing in again.

Within federated identity with multiple partners scenario, both corporate employees and business partners who don&rsquo;t have accounts in the corporate directory should be authenticated. It is widely used in business-to-business applications, applications that require integration with third-party services, and the situations where several companies with different IT systems merged or shared resources.

Federated identity in SaaS applications scenario is used when independent software vendors provide a ready-to-use service for multiple clients or tenants. A suitable identity provider is used to authenticate a tenant. For example, business users may apply their corporate credentials, while tenant&rsquo;s consumers and clients may use their social identity credentials.

Alongside the scenarios where the federated identity pattern is applicable, there are numerous situations when its usage is not recommended or even forbidden. In order to build a more comprehensive view, let&rsquo;s take a close look at some of such scenarios.

Click on the flip cards to learn when this pattern might not be useful.


SCENARIO 1

This pattern is not recommended for use in a situation when one identity provider authenticates application users without any requirement to authenticate using any other identity provider. This scenario is used in business applications with a corporate directory accessible within the application for authentication using a VPN or in a cloud-hosted scenario via a virtual network connection between the on-premises directory and the application.


SCENARIO 2

This pattern is not recommended for use if the application was developed with a different authentication mechanism that applies custom user stores or has no capability to process the negotiation standards used by claims-based technologies. Using retrofitting claims-based authentication and access control can make the application more complicated and less cost-effective.

Loading&hellip;

Microsoft Example

Now, let&rsquo;s consider an example of this pattern application scenario suggested by Microsoft. An organization hosts a multi-tenant software as a service (SaaS) application in Microsoft Azure. The application includes a website that tenants can use to manage the application for their own users. The application allows tenants to access the website by using a federated identity generated by Active Directory Federation Services (ADFS) when a user is authenticated by that organization&rsquo;s own Active Directory.

Click on the hot spots to receive additional information regarding this example.

Tenants authenticate with their own identity provider, in this case, ADFS. After successfully authenticating a tenant, ADFS issues a token.

The client browser forwards this token to the SaaS application&rsquo;s federation provider, which trusts tokens issued by the tenant&rsquo;s ADFS, in order to get back a token that is valid for the SaaS federation provider.

If necessary, the SaaS federation provider performs a transformation on the claims in the token into claims that the application recognizes before returning the new token to the client browser.

The application trusts tokens issued by the SaaS federation provider and uses the token claims to apply authorization rules.

Click&nbsp;here to extend your knowledge about the Federated Identity pattern.

Identity Management Example

Let&rsquo;s consider one more scenario. But first, you should keep in mind that the identity provider can be included in the Identity Management application that integrates with external identity providers. Now, let&rsquo;s consider the diagram below. Think about the process it can visualize.

Now, let&rsquo;s move to the example explanation. The diagram above shows a high-level overview of the real-world implementation of this pattern. In order to build a more comprehensive view, let&rsquo;s follow this example step-by-step.

Click on the step-by-step interactivity to receive the explanation for the visualized example.

Here the Identity Management acts as the Identity Provider for the mobile, web, and desktop apps that have a Trust Relationship with the Identity Management system.

It also integrates with external Identity Providers like Azure AD, ADFS, Social Providers, and other Identity Provider Services.

The Identity Management system has User Administration and Management capabilities where Operations Teams can quickly perform user administration tasks like removing users from the system, controlling access to certain applications/resources, managing password policies, etc. It is much easier for operations teams to handle these in one place rather than looking at 5&ndash;10 different systems.

Gatekeeper Pattern Overview

Another security pattern is called the gatekeeper. This pattern provides an extra layer of security to your applications and services hosted in the cloud. Let&rsquo;s learn more about the problems this pattern aims to solve and how it can be achieved.

Click on the flip cards to explore more.

Context/Risk

Applications expose their functionality to clients by accepting and processing requests. This code usually also performs authentication and validation. This may introduce a vulnerability.

&rsaquo;

Intention

Minimize the risk of clients gaining access to sensitive information and services by compromising the application&rsquo;s hosting environment.

&rsaquo;

Solution

Decouple hosts or tasks that expose public endpoints from the code that processes requests and accesses storage and introduce controlled validation.

Let&rsquo;s figure out how the described solution can be achieved. You can use a facade or a dedicated task that interacts with clients and then hands off the request&mdash;perhaps through a decoupled interface&mdash;to the hosts or tasks that will handle the request. The diagram below provides a high-level overview of this pattern.

Gatekeeper Pattern Factors and Use-cases

This pattern can be used to simply protect storage, or it can be used as a more comprehensive facade to protect all application functions. Let&rsquo;s explore the main factors to be considered when implying the gatekeeper.

Click on the hot spots to learn more about these factors.

The gatekeeper validates all requests and rejects those that don&rsquo;t meet validation requirements.

The gatekeeper doesn&rsquo;t have access to the trusted host&rsquo;s credentials or keys to access storage and services. If the gatekeeper is compromised, the attacker doesn&rsquo;t get access to this sensitive information.

The gatekeeper runs in a limited privilege mode, while the rest of the application runs in the full trust mode required to access storage and services. If the gatekeeper is compromised, it can&rsquo;t directly access the application services or data.

Let&rsquo;s take a closer look at several scenarios when using gatekeeper pattern can be considered a good choice. This pattern is useful for applications that handle sensitive information, expose services that must have a high degree of protection from malicious attacks, or perform mission-critical operations that shouldn&rsquo;t be disrupted. This pattern is also useful for distributed applications where it&rsquo;s necessary to perform request validation separately from the main tasks or to centralize this validation to simplify maintenance and administration. Now, let&rsquo;s move on to the example.

Click on the dropdown to overview Cloud-Hosted Scenario.

In a cloud-hosted scenario, gatekeeper pattern can be implemented by decoupling the gatekeeper role or virtual machine from the trusted roles and services in the application. Do this by using an internal endpoint, a queue, or storage as an intermediate communication mechanism. The figure below illustrates using an internal endpoint.

Valet Key Pattern

Valet key is a useful pattern for situations when users of a cloud application need to upload or download files. The idea is to create temporary tokens that give limited access to a single blob in a cloud storage and have the client upload or download directly to/from that cloud store rather than through the application. Let&rsquo;s learn more about the issues this pattern is aimed to solve.

Click on the step-by-step interactivity to explore more.

Context/Risk

Client programs and web browsers often need to read and write files or data streams to and from an application&rsquo;s storage. Typically, the application will handle the data&rsquo;s movement either by fetching it from storage and streaming it to the client or by reading the uploaded stream from the client and storing it in the data store. However, this approach absorbs valuable resources, such as compute, memory, and bandwidth.

Intention

Applications must securely control access to data in a granular way but still reduce the load on the server by setting up this connection and then allowing the client to communicate directly with the data store to perform the required read or write operations.

Solution

Restrict access to the data store&rsquo;s public connection and provide the client with a key or token that the data store can validate. This will provide time-limited access to specific resources and allow only predefined operations such as reading and writing to storage or uploading and downloading in a web browser.

Applications can create and issue valet keys to client devices and web browsers quickly and easily, allowing clients to perform the required operations without asking the application to directly handle the data transfer. This removes the processing overhead and the impact on performance and scalability from the application and the server. The client uses this token to access a specific resource in the data store for only a specific period and with specific restrictions. After the specified period, the key becomes invalid and won&rsquo;t grant access to the resource.

The organizational structure of the valet key secure pattern is represented in the scheme below. It provides a clear understanding of how one component is connected to another.

Valet Key Pattern Use-Cases

Let&rsquo;s move on to the valet key pattern use cases. There are five scenarios when implementing this pattern can be the best option. Let&rsquo;s learn more about each of them and figure out the advantages this pattern provides in dealing with actual challenges.

Scroll to learn more about the effective usage of the valet key pattern.

The pattern allows to decrease resource loading and improve performance and scalability. When using it, resources shouldn&rsquo;t be locked, and the remote server call is not required. It also allows preventing a single point of failure caused by performing a data transfer through the application code.

Valet key is a good solution for minimizing operational cost. It is resource- and cost-effective to allow direct access to stores and queues. Moreover, it can lead to fewer network roundtrips and may reduce the required number of compute resources.

It is recommended to use a valet key secure pattern in situations when users regularly upload or download data. In particular, this pattern&rsquo;s usage can be effective if the data amount is large or each operation contains large files.

This approach is reasonable to use if an application is limited in compute resources because of hosting limitations or cost considerations. The pattern assists even more if there are many concurrent data uploads or downloads as it allows the application not to process the data transfer.

Use the pattern when the data is stored in a remote data store or a different data center. If the application acts as a gatekeeper, the additional bandwidth of transferring the data between data centers may be required, and then between the application and the data store.

In some other cases, usage of the valet key pattern can rather be damaging than helpful. Let&rsquo;s pay extra attention to the detailed description of such examples.

Click on the dots to learn more about when this pattern should be avoided.

If the application processes the data before it is stored or sent to the client, e.g., if the application executes validation, logs access success, or performs data transformation. However, clients can perform simple operations like compression and decompression.

Using a valet key pattern should also be avoided if the application&rsquo;s design makes it difficult to incorporate the pattern. Keep in mind that using this pattern typically requires a different architectural approach for delivering and receiving data.

Try not to use this pattern if an application needs to maintain audit trails or control how many times the data transfer operation is performed, and the applied valet key mechanism doesn&rsquo;t support notifications that can be used by the server to manage these operations.

Don&rsquo;t use the valet key pattern if the size of the data is restricted, mainly when performing upload operations. The only possible solution is to control the data size after the operation is executed or check the uploaded data's size after a specified period or according to the schedule.

L10: Zero-downtime release

Bookmark

Lesson Introduction

The following lesson will cover the release patterns. You will learn what key steps should be taken before users will be redirected to the new version of the application and what are the main pros and cons of every release pattern described below. You also will get some useful practical tips regarding the implementation of this theoretical knowledge into practice.

Zero-Downtime Release Definition

A zero-downtime release, also known as hot deployment, is when the actual process of switching users from one release to another happens nearly immediately. It is essential to be able to roll back a deployment in case it goes wrong. Blue-green deployments and canary release are advanced techniques to do that. They are efficiently used to perform zero-downtime releases.

Blue-Green Deployment: Overview

Blue-green deployment is a powerful technique to manage releases. The idea is to have two identical versions of the production environment called blue and green. Users of the system are routed to the green environment, which is currently a designated production.

In some situations, there can be different pieces of hardware or different virtual machines running on the same (or different) hardware. There can also be a single operating environment partitioned into separate zones with separate IP addresses for these two slices.

The release of a new version of an application should be performed by the consecutive execution of the set of determined steps. Let&rsquo;s take a closer look at these steps.

Click on the hot spots to overview these steps.

Deploy the application to blue environment.

Let the application warm up (you can do this as you like).

Run smoke tests against the blue environment to ensure it is working correctly.

Change the router configuration to point to the blue environment instead of the green environment.

Now, let&rsquo;s consider an example. Suppose, you have developed a simple cloud-native app&mdash;a mobile game where users earn points by tapping multicolored balloons that fly across the screen. The game&rsquo;s back end is supported by multiple container-based microservices that handle game achievements, scoring, mechanics, communication, and player identification. Now, let&rsquo;s figure out how blue-green deployment is applicable to this scenario.

Click on the step-by-step interactivity to view the example.

Hundreds of users start playing the game after its initial release. They are logging thousands of transactions every minute. Your DevOps team has encouraged you to release early and often, which is why you&rsquo;re about to release a minor update to the mechanics microservice that increases the size and speed of the red balloon.

Instead of waiting until midnight to push the update to the production environment (when the lowest number of users are active), you&rsquo;re using a blue-green deployment model to update the app during peak use time. And you are going to do it with zero downtime.

You are able to do this because you took the mechanics microservice in the production environment (blue) and copied it to an identical&mdash;but separate&mdash;container (green). After you increased the red balloons&rsquo; size and speed in the green environment, it passed through Q/A and staging (which were perhaps automated by an open-source stress test project like Jenkins) before it was pushed to the production environment alongside the active blue environment.

The ops team can use a load balancer to redirect each user&rsquo;s next transaction from blue to green, and&mdash;once all production traffic is filtered through the green environment&mdash;the blue environment is brought offline. Blue can either stand by as a disaster recovery option or become the container for the next update.

Blue-green Deployment Advantages and Hints

Now, let&rsquo;s pay attention to the advantages of the blue-green deployment, which include minimum downtime and rapid way to rollback, as well as tips for using this pattern.

Click on the flip cards to explore the advantages and hints of using blue-green deployment.

Advantages

  • Minimum Downtime - switchover takes less than a second to be completed.
  • Rapid Way to Rollback - once something went wrong, you can switch the router back to the green environment and use blue environment to debug what went wrong.

Hints

  • Switch the application into read-only mode just before the switchover.
  • Transactions should be fed to both the new and old databases from the latest version of the application.
  • The application should be designed in a way to let the database migrate independently from the upgrade process.

Besides the hints provided above, there are several best practices for the implementation of Blue-green deployment suggested by the community. Their main concerns include choosing load balancing over DNS switching, rolling update execution, monitoring environment with correct alerts, automation, and making the code forward and backward compatible. Let&rsquo;s learn more about each of them.

Click on the dots to examine best practices.

Choose Load Balancing Over DNS Switching

When switching between environments, you need to make your domain to eventually point to different servers. Don&rsquo;t go to the DNS records. Instead, use load balancing. Load balancers enable you to set your new servers immediately, without having to depend on the DNS mechanism. The DNS record will always point to the Load Balancer, and you only change the servers behind it. This way you can be absolutely sure that all traffic comes to the new production environment instead of the old one.

Execute a Rolling Update

Switching all your servers from an old version to a new one at once may result in downtime. To avoid that, you can execute a &ldquo;rolling update&rdquo;. This means that instead of switching from all Blue servers to all Green servers in a single cut-off, you can work with an integrated environment. Add one new server, retire one old server, and repeat this until all the new servers are inside. One thing to make sure of, though, is that your new code can run alongside your old code because they will be running together side-by-side.

Monitor Your Environments with the Correct Alerts

The need to monitor production is obvious but monitoring the non-production environment is also essential. However, non-production monitoring is less critical. Since the same environment can play both as production and non-production, you will need an easy way to toggle the alerting between the two states. This can be achieved by using a different API token for production/non-production reporting to your APM solution or by programmatically changing the alert policy on the APM of the environment when its role changes.

Automate

You should script as many actions as possible in the switching process instead of doing a manual set of actions. There are some benefits to such an approach. First, the switch will happen faster if its steps are automated. Second, nothing needs to be remembered. Also, it is safer as manual work is more error-prone. What is more, this approach enables self-service: having a switch button running an automated script enables everyone with the right permissions to do it without being dependent on someone that knows the exact steps needed.

Make Your Code Backward and Forward Compatible

The new and old versions will run side-by-side during the switch process, so make sure both versions can co-exist. To avoid downtime, break the update into a few &ldquo;mini-updates&rdquo;. For example, you&rsquo;re changing a field name from &ldquo;user_name&rdquo; to &ldquo;username&rdquo;. Release an intermediate version of the code that works with both &ldquo;user_name&rdquo; and &ldquo;username&rdquo;. Rename the field to &ldquo;username&rdquo; across all records in the database. Release the final code version, supporting &ldquo;username&rdquo;, and remove the old code supporting &ldquo;user_name&rdquo; completely.

Canary Release Description

Canary release is a technique to reduce the risk of introducing a new software version in production by slowly rolling out the change to a small subset of users before rolling it out to the entire infrastructure and making it available to everybody.

It is usually a safe assumption that you only have one version of your software in production at a time. If you have an extremely large production environment, it&rsquo;s impossible to create a meaningful capacity testing environment (unless your application&rsquo;s architecture employs end-to-end sharing). How do you ensure a new version of your application won&rsquo;t perform poorly?

You start by deploying the new version of your software to a subset of your infrastructure, to which no users are routed. When you are happy with the new version, you can start routing a few selected users to it.

Swipe the illustration to the left to see deployed new version with no routed users and to the right to see the illustration for routing new users.

There are different strategies on how to choose which users will see the new version. Let's pay a special attention to the ways of users routing and the scenarios they can be used in.

Click on the video to overview these strategies. Alternatively, you may click hereto download a text script to find out what you will learn.

When all the users have been routed to the new version, the migrate phase is over. At this point, the old infrastructure can be decompiled. Let&rsquo;s figure out how it can be visualized.

Move the pieces of the diagram below in order to rebuild the scheme. Click on the piece you want to move, and then on the piece you want to be replaced with the first one.

Now, let&rsquo;s pay attention to some real-life examples of using canary releases.

Using Partitioning Strategies with Canary Releases

First, it&rsquo;s important to mention that in large, distributed scenarios, instead of using a router to decide which users will be redirected to the new version, it is also common to use different partitioning strategies.

For example, if you have geographically distributed users, you can roll out the new version to a region or a specific location first. If you have multiple brands, you can roll out to a single brand first, etc. Facebook chooses to use a strategy with various canaries, the first one being visible only to their internal employees and having all the Feature Toggles (will be explained further in the lesson) turned on so they can detect problems with new features early.

Loading drag and drop problem.

Netflix Example

In partnership with Google, Netflix has open-sourced Kayenta, a platform for Automated Canary Analysis (ACA). Kayenta leverages lessons learned over the years of delivering rapid and reliable changes into production at Netflix. It is a crucial component of delivery at Netflix as it reduces the risk of making changes in the production environment.

Netflix augments the canary release process and uses three clusters, all serving the same traffic with different amounts. Let&rsquo;s pay more attention to these clusters.

Click on the flip cards to figure out which clusters are used.

Production Cluster

The production cluster is unchanged and is the version of the software that is currently running. This cluster may run any number of instances.

Baseline Cluster

The baseline cluster runs the same version of code and configuration as the production cluster. Typically, three instances are created.

Canary Cluster

The canary cluster runs the proposed changes of code or configuration. As in the baseline cluster, three instances are typical.

The production cluster receives the majority of traffic, while the baseline and canary each receive a small amount. How this delineation of traffic routing occurs depends on the type of traffic, but a typical configuration leverages a load balancer to add the baseline and canary instances into the regular pool of existing cases. There are two platforms involved in this process in Netflix.

Click on the tabs to learn more about these platforms.

Spinnaker &mdash; a continuous delivery platform&mdash;handles the lifecycle of the baseline and canary clusters. It runs one or more iterations of the canary analysis step and decides to continue, rollback, or prompt manual intervention to proceed. If the new version is determined to be safe, the deployment is allowed to continue, and the production change is fully rolled out into a new cluster. If not, Spinnaker aborts the canary process, and all traffic will be routed to the production cluster.

Kayenta is the next-generation automated canary analysis platform and is tightly integrated with Spinnaker. The Kayenta platform is responsible for assessing the risk of a canary release and checks for significant degradation between the baseline and canary. This process comprises two primary stages: metric retrieval (at this step, the key metrics are retrieved from the baseline and canary clusters) and judgment (at this stage, the metrics collected from the baseline and canary).

Refer here to learn more about how Netflix uses canary releases.

Canary Release Benefits and Hints

Now, when you became familiar with the primary mechanism of canary releases and overviewed some real-life examples, let&rsquo;s gain more information about the benefits of the canary release alongside some tips for using this pattern.

Click on the dropdowns to learn more about the benefits and hints of the canary releases.

  • It makes rolling back easy: just stop routing users to the bad version, and you can investigate the problem.
  • You can use it for A/B testing by routing some users to the new version and others to the old version.
  • You can check if the application meets capacity requirements by gradually ramping up the load, slowly routing more and more users to the application, and measuring the application&rsquo;s response time and metrics like CPU usage, I/O, and memory usage.
  • It is hard to utilize it if the users have your software installed on their own computers or mobile devices.
  • Any shared resource needs to work with all versions of the application you want to have in production.
  • Supporting multiple versions is painful, so keep the number of canaries to a minimum.

Canary Release: Good and Bad Use-cases

Although canary releases have a variety of advantages (which were already examined above), there are some situations when you should not use this pattern. In order to avoid mistakes, let&rsquo;s explore the good and bad use-cases for canary releases.

Click on the dots to learn more about when to use and avoid canary releases.

Use canary releases

  • An application consists of multiple (micro)services that are changing at independent rates, and the verification of functionality must be conducted in a realistic (ideally, production) environment.
  • There is a high operational risk of deploying new functionality, which can be mitigated by experimenting with directing a small percentage of traffic to the new deployment.
  • A service depends on an upstream system that cannot effectively be tested against. The only reliable method to validate a successful integration is to integrate with this service.

Do not use canary releases

  • You are working on a mission, safety, or life-critical system that cannot tolerate failure. No one wants to see the canary release of a nuclear meltdown safety mechanism.
  • End users will be overly sensitive to canary results. For example, extra care would be required if using canary release for the software that manipulates large amounts of financial transactions.
  • The experiment would require the modification of back-end data (or the data store schema) in a way that is not compatible with the current service requirements.

Feature Flags Releases Description and Use-cases

Finally, let&rsquo;s briefly overview feature flags. Feature flags (also known as feature toggles or feature switches) are a software development technique that turns certain functionality on and off during runtime without deploying new code. This allows better control and more experimentation over the full lifecycle of features. The idea behind feature flags is to build conditional feature branches into code in order to make logic available only to specific groups of users at a time. If the flag is &ldquo;on&rdquo;, new code is executed. If the flag is &ldquo;off&rdquo;, the code is skipped.

A feature flag release varies from a canary release, as feature flags are used to expose a specific feature to a small subgroup of users. A canary release exposes a particular version of the entire application or service. There are many benefits to incorporating feature toggles into your release process. The following are some common use cases.

Scroll to discover feature flags use-cases.

Testing in Production


Feature flags allow development teams to test new features in production while mitigating the risk of a poor release by providing a way to quickly roll back the feature via a kill switch if necessary. They allow validating the functionality of new feature releases in the real world while minimizing the risk and encourage trunk-based development, which helps prevent merge conflicts from divergent code paths.

Quicker Release Cycles


Using feature flags, a team can modify a system&rsquo;s behavior without making disruptive code changes to the live code. Thus, one of the feature flags&rsquo; important benefits is the simplicity of their deployment in the development process. Feature flags decouple feature lifecycle management from code deployment, freeing up the engineering team to work on other tasks.

Rollback / Kill Switch


Using feature flags significantly simplifies enabling or disabling new features. If a bug is discovered in a new feature, it can be rolled back instantly without changing your source code. This is useful for mobile app developers, who can use feature flags to release or roll back new features without going through the lengthy app store review process.

Server-Side A/B Testing


Developers can implement A/B tests using feature flags by enabling a feature for half of the segment of users, and disabling the feature for the other half, and seeing how the two perform against each other for a certain metric. Feature flags allow to A/B test various features within products with no need for code deployment. Google, Facebook, Amazon, and Netflix A/B test new features before deploying to their full user base.

Feature Gating


Feature flags can be used to implement targeted rollouts of features to a specific subset of your users. This can be great for A/B testing features for specific segments of your audience. Still, it can also be used to release features to only a subset of your users, for example, granting users in your enterprise tier access to features that aren&rsquo;t available in lower tiers.

Continuous Deployment


Feature flags have the ability to allow quick learning. Feature flagging enables companies to continuously deliver and deploy software to their users in a faster way. The use of feature flags allows companies to perform gradual feature rollouts, fix bugs in the code without redeploying, experience a more streamlined development cycle, and do rollbacks of code more easily.

Lesson Summary

In the completed lesson, you familiarized yourself with release patterns. In particular, you got acquainted with the description of zero-downtime release, paid attention to blue-green deployment, analyzed its benefits, and were provided with some best practices of how it could be implemented. What is more, you overviewed canary releases and discovered which real-world companies use them. Finally, you were introduced to feature flags releases and explored their main use-cases.

L7: Architectural Patterns. Integration Patterns

Bookmark

Lesson Introduction

This lesson provides an introduction to the integration pattern as well as gives more detailed information about messaging systems and their components. Understanding of the integration styles, message concepts, and system management patterns can help guide solution architects toward employing practices that translate across any integration project regardless of the industry.

Integration Patterns

Integration aims to make component agnostic and usable quickly across the business, so it can be accessed and handled by its constituents. And in order to make that data usable even more quickly, integration patterns can be created to standardize the integration process.

There are commonly used patterns in the integration categorythe File Transfer, Shared database, Remote Procedure Invocation, and Messaging. The majority of the Messaging patterns are summarized below. The upcoming sections look at some of them in more detail.

Click on the hot spots to learn more about them.

Messaging patterns: Message; Command Message; Document Message; Event Message; Request-Reply; Return Address; Correlation Identifier; Message Sequence; Message Expiration; Format Indicator.

Message Routing: Pipes-and-Filters; Message Router; Content-based Router; Message Filter; Dynamic Router; Recipient List; Splitter; Aggregator; Resequencer; Composed Msg. Processor; Scatter-Gather; Routing Slip; Process Manager; Message Broker.

Message Transformation: Message Translator; Envelope Wrapper; Content Enricher; Content Filter; Claim Check; Normalizer; Canonical Data Model.

Messaging Endpoints: Message Endpoint; Messaging Gateway; Messaging Mapper; Transactional Client; Polling Consumer; Event-driven Consumer; Competing; Consumers; Message Dispatcher; Selective Consumer; Durable Subscriber; Idempotent Receiver; Service Activator.

Messaging Channels: Message Channel; Point-to-Point Channel; Publish-Subscr. Channel; Datatype Channel; Invalid Message Channel; Dead Letter Channel; Guaranteed Delivery; Channel Adapter; Messaging Bridge; Message Bus.

Systems Mgmt: Control Bus; Detour; Wire Tap; Message History; Message Store; Smart Proxy; Test Message; Channel Purger.

Messaging As a Way of Applications' Integration

This lesson explains how to use messaging to integrate applications. Messaging is a technology that enables high-speed, asynchronous, program-to-program communication with reliable delivery. Programs communicate by sending packets of data called messages to each other.

Click on the flip cards to learn about messaging process components.

Channels

Channels, also known as queues, are logical pathways that connect the programs and convey messages. A channel behaves like a collection or array of messages, but one that is magically shared across multiple computers and can be used concurrently by multiple applications.

Sender

A sender or producer is a program that sends a message by writing a message to a channel.

Receiver

A receiver or consumer is a program that receives a message by reading (and deleting) it from a channel.

Messaging capabilities are typically provided by a separate software system called a messaging system or message-oriented middleware, which manages messaging in the way a database system manages data persistence.

If you are wondering why you should use messaging, there are some reasons. Messaging is more immediate than File Transfer, better encapsulated than Shared Database, and more reliable than Remote Procedure Invocation. However, that's just the beginning of the advantages that can be gained using messaging.

Messaging Gateway

How to encapsulate access to the messaging system from the rest of the application? Use a Messaging Gateway, a class that wraps messaging-specific method calls and exposes domain-specific methods to the application. The Messaging Gateway encapsulates messaging-specific code (e.g., the code required to send or receive a message) and separates it from the rest of the application code. This way, only the Messaging Gateway code knows about the messaging system; the rest of the application code does not.

The Messaging Gateway provides a business function to the rest of the application in a way that it doesn't require the application to set such properties as Message.MessageReadPropertyFilter.AppSpecific. It is a gateway that exposes methods like GetCreditScore that allows you to accept strictly typed parameters as any other method. A Messaging Gateway is considered as a messaging-specific version of the more common Gateway pattern.

Many Messaging Gateways send a message to another component and expect a reply. Such a Messaging Gateway can be implemented in two different ways: Blocking (Synchronous) Messaging Gateway and Event-Driven (Asynchronous) Messaging Gateway. Now, let's figure out some reasons to use this pattern.

Click on the tabs to learn more about why to use Messaging Gateway.

The Messaging Gateway makes it easier for the application to maintain state if it allows the application to pass a reference to an arbitrary set of data to the request method. The Messaging Gateway will then pass this data back to the application with the callback. This way, the application has all the necessary data available when the asynchronous callback is invoked. This type of interaction is called ACT (Asynchronous Completion Token).

Messaging Gateways make great testing vehicles. Because all the nasty messaging code is wrapped behind a narrow, domain-specific interface, you can easily create an implementation of this interface. Simply separate interface and implementation and provide two implementations: one "real" implementation that accesses the messaging infrastructure and a "fake" implementation for testing purposes.

Request-Reply

When an application sends a message, how can it get a response from the receiver? Send a pair of Request-Reply messages, each on its own channel. When two applications communicate via Messaging, the communication is one-way. In some cases, applications may want a two-way conversation.

The Request-Reply integration pattern facilitates two-way communication by ensuring that a sender gets a response or reply from the receiver after sending a request message. This pattern sends a pair of Request-Reply messages, each on its own channel. Request-Reply has two participants.

Click on the hot spots to learn more about these participants.

Requestor. Sends a request message and waits for a reply message.

Replier. Receives the request message and responds with a reply message.

Request Channel. The request channel can be a Point-to-Point Channel or a Publish-Subscribe Channel. The difference is whether the request should be broadcast to all interested parties or should only be processed by a single consumer.

Reply Channel. The reply channel is almost always point-to-point because it usually makes no sense to broadcast repliesthey should only be returned to the requestor.

An example of using Request-Reply is SOAP messages. SOAP messages come in Request-Reply pairs. A SOAP request message indicates a service the sender wishes to invoke on the receiver, whereas a SOAP response message contains the result of the service invocation. The response message either contains a result value or a faultthe SOAP equivalent of an exception.

You can also find some additional examples for using Request-Reply here.

Guaranteed Delivery

How can the sender make sure that a message will be delivered, even if the messaging system fails? Use Guaranteed Delivery to make messages persistent so that they are not lost even if the messaging system crashes.

Click on the video to explore more about Guaranteed Delivery. Alternatively, you may click here to download a text script to find out what you will learn.

Now, let's figure out when it is better to use or avoid this pattern. Persistence increases reliability but at the expense of performance. Thus, if it's OK to lose messages when the messaging system crashes or is shut down, avoid using Guaranteed Delivery so that messages will move through the messaging system faster. Let's overview the scenarios when you should consider using Guaranteed Delivery.

Click on the dots to learn more about Guaranteed Delivery use-cases.

High-traffic Scenarios

Guaranteed Delivery can consume a large amount of disk space in high-traffic scenarios. If a producer generates hundreds or thousands of messages per second, then a network outage that lasts multiple hours could use up a huge amount of disk space. Because the network is unavailable, the messages have to be stored on the producing computer's local disk drive, which may not be designed to hold this much data. For these reasons, some messaging systems allow you to configure a retry timeout parameter that specifies how long messages are buffered inside the messaging system. In some high-traffic applications (e.g., streaming stock quotes to terminals), this timeout may have to be set to a short time span, for example, a few minutes.

Testing and Debugging

It can also be useful to turn off Guaranteed Delivery during testing and debugging. This makes it easy to purge all message channels by stopping and restarting the messaging server. Messages that are still queued up can make it very tedious to debug even simple messaging programs. For example, you may have a sender and a receiver connected by a Point-to-Point Channel. If a message is still stored on the channel, the receiver will process that message before any new message that the sender produces. This is a common debugging pitfall in asynchronous, guaranteed messaging. Many commercial messaging implementations also allow you to purge queues individually to allow a fresh restart during testing.

Now, let's figure out how this pattern can be applied in real-life examples. The first example describes the use of Guaranteed Delivery in a stock trading system; the second refers to the IBM WebSphere MQ, which is a family of message-oriented middleware products.

Click on the dropdowns to explore examples.

In a stock trading system, trade requests and trade confirmations should probably be sent with Guaranteed Delivery to help ensure that none are lost. Likewise, change-of-address announcements should probably be sent with Guaranteed Delivery. On the other hand, price updates probably do not require Guaranteed Delivery; losing some of them is not significant, and their frequency makes the overhead of Guaranteed Delivery prohibitive.

The stock trading example says that some price-change subscribers may wish to be durable. If so, then perhaps the price-change channel should guarantee delivery as well. Yet other subscribers may not need to be durable nor want to suffer the overhead of Guaranteed Delivery. How can these different needs be met? The system may wish to implement two price-change channels, one with Guaranteed Delivery and another without. Only subscribers that require all updates should subscribe to the persistent channel, and their subscriptions should be durable. The publisher may wish to publish updates less frequently on the persistent channel because of its increased overhead.

In WebSphere MQ, Guaranteed Delivery can be set on a per-channel basis or a per-message basis. If the channel is not persistent, the messages cannot be persistent. If the channel is persistent, the channel can be configured such that all messages sent on that channel are automatically persistent or such that an individual message can be sent persistently or non-persistently.

Aggregator

How to combine the results of individual but related messages so that they can be processed as a whole? Use a stateful filter, an aggregator, to collect and store individual messages until a complete set of related messages has been received. Then, the aggregator publishes a single message distilled from the individual messages.

The aggregator is a special filter that receives a stream of messages and identifies messages that are correlated. Once a complete set of messages has been received, the aggregator collects information from each correlated message and publishes a single, aggregated message to the output channel for further processing.

There are a number of strategies for aggregator completeness conditions. The available strategies primarily depend on whether you know how many messages to expect or not. The aggregator could know the number of sub-messages to expect because it received a copy of the original composite message or because each individual message contains the total count. So, let's consider aggregation strategies.

Scroll to learn more about these strategies.

"Wait for All"

Wait until all responses are received. An incomplete order may not be meaningful. So, if not all items are received within a certain timeout period, an error condition should be raised by the aggregator. This approach may give you the best basis for decision-making but may also be the slowest and most brittle (and you need to know how many messages to expect).

"Time Out"

Wait for a specified length of time for responses and then make a decision by evaluating those responses received within that time limit. If no responses are received, the system may report an exception or retry. This is useful if incoming responses are scored, and only the message with the highest score is used. This approach is common in "bidding" scenarios.

"First Best"


Wait only until the first (fastest) response is received and ignore all other responses. You should keep in mind that this approach is the fastest but ignores a lot of information. However, note that it may be practical in a bidding or quoting scenario where response time is critical.

"Time Out with Override"

Wait for a specified amount of time or until a message with a preset minimum score has been received. In this scenario, you are willing to abort early if you find a very favorable response; otherwise, you keep on going until time is up. If no clear winner was found at that point, rank-ordering among all the messages received so far occurs.

"External Event"

Sometimes the aggregation is concluded by the arrival of an external business event. E.g., in the financial industry, the end of the trading day may signal the end of an aggregation of incoming price quotes. The aggregator can listen for the Event Message on a special control channel or receive a specially formatted message that indicates the end of the aggregation.

Select the "Best" Answer

This approach assumes that there is a single best answer, e.g., the lowest bid for an identical item. The aggregator can make the decision and only pass the "best" message on. In real life, selection criteria are rarely this simple. E.g., the "best" bid for an item may depend on the time of delivery, the number of available items, whether the vendor is on the preferred vendor list, etc.

Condense Data

An Aggregator can be used to reduce message traffic from a high-traffic source. In these cases, it may make sense to compute an average of individual messages or add numeric fields from each message into a single message. This works best if each message represents a numeric value, for example, the number of orders received.

Collect Data for Later Evaluation

It is not always possible for an aggregator to make the decision of how to select the best answer. In those cases, it makes sense to use an Aggregator to collect the individual messages and combine them into a single message. This message may simply be a compilation of the individual's message data. The aggregation decision may be made later by a separate component.

In many instances, the aggregation strategy is driven by parameters. For example, a strategy that waits for a specified amount of time can be configured with the maximum wait time.

Now, let's explore how aggregators can be useful in different aggregations. Let's consider a Loan broker as an example. An Aggregator can be used to select the best loan quote from the loan quote messages returned by the banks. The loan broker example uses an initialized Aggregatorthe Recipient List informs the aggregator of the number of quote messages to expect.

Guaranteed Delivery and Aggregator Example

Let's figure out how an Aggregator can be used as Missing Message Detector. The system sends a message through a sequence of components, which are unfortunately quite unreliable. Even using Guaranteed Delivery will not correct this problem because, typically, the systems themselves fail after they consumed a message. Because the applications are not Transactional Clients, the message-in-progress is lost. Now, let's pay attention to the scheme below.


To help remedy this situation, an incoming is routed through two parallel paths: once through the required but unreliable components and once around the components using Guaranteed Delivery. An Aggregator recombines the messages from the two paths. Now, let's examine this example more specifically.

Click on the step-by-step interactivity to explore the process shown in the scheme above.

The aggregator uses a "Time Out with Override" completeness condition, which means that the aggregator completes if either the timeout is reached or the two associated messages have been received.

The aggregation algorithm depends on which condition is fulfilled first. If two messages are received, the processed message is passed on without modification. If the timeout event occurs, you know that one of the components failed and "ate" the message.

As a result, you instruct the aggregator to publish an error message that alerts the operators that one of the components has failed. Unfortunately, the components have to be restarted manually, but a more sophisticated configuration could likely restart the component and re-send any lost messages. Unfortunately, the components have to be restarted manually, but a more sophisticated configuration could likely restart the component and re-send any lost messages.

Content Enricher

How to communicate with another system if the message originator does not have all the required data items available? Use a specialized transformer, a content enricher, to access an external data source in order to augment a message with missing information.

You should be aware that when sending messages from one system to another, it is common for the target system to require more information than the source system can provide.

Click on the dots to learn more about content enricher.

For example, incoming address messages may just contain the ZIP code because the designers felt that storing a redundant state code would be superfluous, or an order message sent by the order management system may just contain an order number, but you need to find the customer ID associated with that order, so you can pass it to the customer management system.

The Content Enricher uses information inside the incoming message (e.g., key fields) to retrieve data from an external source. After the Content Enricher retrieves the required data from the resource, it appends the data to the message. The original information from the incoming message may be carried over into the resulting message or may no longer be needed, depending on the specific needs of the receiving application.

Content Enricher Examples

Let's consider the following example. A hospital scheduling system publishes a message announcing that the patient has completed a doctor's visit. The message contains the patient's first name, his or her patient ID, and the date of the visit. In order for the accounting system to log this visit and inform the insurance company, it requires the full patient name, the insurance carrier, and the patient's social security number. However, the scheduling system does not store this information; it is contained in the customer care system. There are three options, as described below.

Click on the tabs to overview these options.

The scheduling system can be modified so it can store additional information. When the customer's information changes in the customer care system, the changes need to be replicated to the scheduling system. The scheduling system can now send a message that includes all required information. Unfortunately, this approach requires a modification to the scheduling system's internal structure. In most cases, the scheduling system is a packaged application and may not allow this type of modification. Also, even if the scheduling system is customizable, you need to consider that you are making a change to the system based on the specific needs of another system. For example, if you also want to send a letter to the patient confirming the visit, you have to change the scheduling system again to accommodate the customer's mailing address.

The scheduling system could request the SSN and carrier data from the customer care system just before it is sending the "Doctor Visit" message. This solves the first problemyou no longer have to modify the storage of the scheduling system. However, the scheduling system needs to know that the SSN and carrier information is required in order to notify the accounting system. Therefore, the semantics of the message is more similar to "Notify Insurance" than "Doctor Visit". In a loosely coupled system, you rather send an event message and let the other systems decide what to do. In addition, this solution couples the scheduling system more tightly to the customer care system. This ties the scheduling system to both the accounting system and the customer care system. This type of coupling is undesirable because it leads to brittle integration solutions.

The message can be sent to the customer care system first instead of the accounting system. The customer care system can then fetch all the required information and send a message with all the required data to the accounting system. This decouples the scheduling system nicely from the subsequent flow of the message. However, now you implement the business rule that the insurance company receives a bill after the patient visits the doctor inside the customer care system. This requires modifying the logic inside the customer care system. If the customer care system is a packaged application, this modification may be impossible. Even if it is implemented, the customer care system is now indirectly responsible for sending bill messages. If some of the fields have to be retrieved from other systems, it is the same situation as in the beginning.

Now, let's figure out how to apply a Content Enricher to this use-case. You can insert the Content Enricher to retrieve the additional data from the customer care system, as shown in the scheme below.

This way, the scheduling system is nicely decoupled from having to deal with insurance information or the customer care system. All it has to do is publish the "Doctor Visit" message. The Content Enricher component takes care of retrieving the required data. The accounting system also remains independent of the customer care system.

If you want to receive some more examples, let's have a look at one additional use-case for the Content Enricher.

Click on the dropdown to discover additional use-case.

A Content Enricher is also commonly used when communicating with external parties that require messages to be compliant with a specific message standard. Most of these standards require large messages with a long list of data. You can usually simplify your internal operations significantly if you keep internal messages as simple as possible and then use the Content Enricher to add the missing fields whenever you send a message outside of the organization. Likewise, you can use a Content Filter to strip unnecessary information from incoming messages (see the scheme below).

Message History

How can you effectively analyze and debug the flow of messages in a loosely coupled system? You should attach a Message History, which contains a list of all applications that the message passed through after it was originated, to the message.

The advantage of the message-based systems is the loose coupling between users, which allows the message sender and recipient to make no prediction about the identity of each other. When retrieving a message from a message channel, a message recipient neither know nor care which application sent the message to the channel. The message doesn't refer to any specific sender, and according to the definition, it is considered as self-contained. This fact is known as an architectural strength of message-based systems.

Move the pieces of the diagram below in order to rebuild the scheme. Click on the piece you want to move, and then on the piece you want to be replaced with the first one.

However, one and the same property may complicate the process of debugging and analyzing dependencies. Is it possible to analyze the effect of a change in the message format if you are not sure where a message goes, and, moreover, is it hard to fix a problem with the message if you don't know which application issued a message? The list of all components that the message passed through is included in the Message History. The originator and each component that handles the message adds one entry to the list. The Message History should be included in the message header as it comprises system-specific control information. If you keep this information in the header, the message body, which contains application-specific data, will be separated from it. Now, let's pay attention to the example.

Many EAI integration suites include support for a Message History. For example, the message header of every ActiveEnterprise message includes a tracking field that maintains a list of all components through which the message has passed. In this context, it is important to note that a TIBCO ActiveEnterprise component assigns outgoing messages the same message ID as the consumed message. This makes tracking of messages through multiple components easier, but it also means that the message ID is not a system-wide unique property because multiple individual messages share the same ID.

If you know to read more about integration patterns, pay attention to this book.

Lesson Summary

This lesson was focused on the application integration patterns. You have learned about several of the most common ones and the way of their implementation into each step of the message communication pipeline. The general understanding of integration styles and system management patterns helps solution architects use integration practices regardless of the industry the project is related to.
